title: Trump adviser Navarro signals caution on further China tariffs over Russian oil
description:
White House trade adviser Peter Navarro said the U.S. is not rushing to impose additional tariffs on China over its purchases of Russian oil, despite having just raised duties on Indian imports for the same reason.

Responding to questions about whether Beijing would face secondary tariffs similar to those announced for India, Navarro noted that China is already subject to a 50% tariff on many goods. “We don't want to get to a point where we actually hurt ourselves,” he said, signalling a more measured approach.

Navarro added that Washington is monitoring China’s energy ties with Russia but said, “Let’s wait and see,” suggesting that no immediate action is planned.

The remarks come as the U.S. tightens trade penalties on countries continuing to buy Russian energy, but also underscores concerns about economic self-harm from escalating the tariff war further.

Trump earlier, where I cautioned he'd have to pull his head in because China has the upper hand over him:

  • Trump is threatening China with an extra 25% tariff over Russia oil buys.
This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to previous tensions between the US and China, the trade war in 2018-2019.
explanation: The news suggests a cautious approach by the US towards imposing additional tariffs on China over its purchases of Russian oil. This is despite the US having recently increased duties on Indian imports for the same reason. White House trade adviser, Peter Navarro, indicated that the US is not rushing to escalate the tariff war with China, a major global economy, as it could potentially harm the US economy itself. However, the US is closely monitoring China's energy ties with Russia, which may lead to future action if deemed necessary. This cautious approach shows a recognition of the potential economic self-harm from escalating the tariff war further. It's likely to have a negative impact on the oil and gas market, as well as broader indices such as the S&P 500, due to the uncertainty it creates. This situation bears resemblance to the previous trade tensions between the US and China in 2018-2019, which led to market volatility.

title: China July 2025 trade data shows USD denominated exports +7.2% y/y (vs +5.4% expected)
description:
Better than expected Chinese exports in July 2025.

Exports +7.2% y/y

  • expected +5.4%, prior 5.8%

Imports +4.1% y/y

  • expected -1.0%, prior +1.1%

Trade balance is a surplus of 84.2bn USD

  • expected 105bn, prior 114.8bn

Exports to the US are down 21.6% y/y in July, but of course trans shipments are hidden in these numebrs

These are still solid figures from China.

--

For the YTD number, January - July:

  • exports +6.1% y/y
  • imports -2.7% y/y
  • trade balance a whopping 683.5bn USD
  • YTD exports to the US are down 12.6% y/y (but of course trans shipment is difficult to discern and there is plenty going on) while imports down 10.3% y/y

--

The yuan is not doing much on the data release, USD/CNH just a few tics up circa 7.1840

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to trade data releases, fluctuations in export and import percentages have historically influenced the value of the yuan and the trade balance.
explanation: The article shows that China's trade data for July 2025 is better than expected with USD denominated exports increasing by 7.2% year over year (y/y), against an expectation of 5.4%. Imports also increased by 4.1% y/y, contrary to a predicted decrease of 1.0%. However, the trade balance is a surplus of USD 84.2bn, less than the expected USD 105bn. The decrease in exports to the US by 21.6% y/y and a year-to-date decrease of 12.6% y/y indicate a slowdown in trade between the two countries. The yuan's value remained steady despite the release of this data. While the overall figures are solid, the decrease in trade with the US and a lower than expected trade surplus could potentially have a negative impact on the Chinese economy, hence the negative impact score.

title: Trump says billions of dollars are flowing into the US as reciprocal tariffs take effect
description:
From the man himself:

"RECIPROCAL TARIFFS TAKE EFFECT AT MIDNIGHT TONIGHT! BILLIONS OF DOLLARS, LARGELY FROM COUNTRIES THAT HAVE TAKEN ADVANTAGE OF THE UNITED STATES FOR MANY YEARS, LAUGHING ALL THE WAY, WILL START FLOWING INTO THE USA. THE ONLY THING THAT CAN STOP AMERICA’S GREATNESS WOULD BE A RADICAL LEFT COURT THAT WANTS TO SEE OUR COUNTRY FAIL!"

"IT’S MIDNIGHT!!! BILLIONS OF DOLLARS IN TARIFFS ARE NOW FLOWING INTO THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA!"

Well, it's not just going to be tariffs revenue now would it? Inflation is also coming. As for the supposed billions flowing in (he's not wrong there as tariff revenue was $30 billion last month, marking a 242% increase compared to July last year), it's all going to be used to little by little try and make up for the ballooning US debt/deficit. I mean, is there anything better that they can do with it at this point?

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the imposition of tariffs by the Trump administration in 2018, which led to increased government revenue but also an escalation in trade tensions.
explanation: President Trump's announcement of reciprocal tariffs taking effect, which he claims will bring billions of dollars into the US, could have a mixed impact on the financial markets. On one hand, the increase in tariff revenue, as evidenced by the $30 billion generated last month, could be seen as a positive factor for the US economy. However, it's important to note that these funds are expected to be used largely for offsetting the growing US debt and deficit, rather than for productive investments or stimulus measures. Additionally, the implementation of new tariffs could potentially escalate trade tensions and cause uncertainty in the markets. This could negatively impact investor sentiment and potentially lead to volatility in the stock, commodities, and forex markets. Furthermore, the mention of possible inflation suggests that the tariffs could lead to increased costs for consumers and businesses, which could further dampen economic activity and market performance.

title: Swiss Federal Council to hold extraordinary meeting as trade delegation returns from US
description:
The meeting will be held this afternoon as key figures in Switzerland now need to think about what to do next after the trade delegation returns home empty-handed. Well, it was to be expected as there was not even a meeting arrange with Trump. And if there was a deal to be struck, you'd know he would want to be present to show his face.

In any case, Switzerland are now facing up against 39% tariffs as Trump's reciprocal tariffs go into effect. But the good news is that at least for now, that excludes pharmaceuticals (and also gold).

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
patterns: This situation is reminiscent of the US-China trade war where the US imposed high tariffs leading to a negative impact on the Chinese market.
explanation: The Swiss Federal Council is set to hold an extraordinary meeting following the return of the trade delegation from the US, which was unable to secure a deal. This outcome was anticipated as there was no meeting arranged with President Trump, who is known for his hands-on approach to such negotiations. As a result, Switzerland is now facing a potential 39% tariff as part of Trump's reciprocal tariff policy. However, there is some positive news as these tariffs do not apply to pharmaceuticals and gold. This situation could have a negative impact on the Swiss market, particularly for industries not exempt from the tariffs. The potential for increased costs could lead to a decrease in trade between the US and Switzerland, potentially impacting the Swiss economy. However, the pharmaceutical and gold sectors may see less of an impact due to their exemption.

title: France June trade balance -€7.6 billion vs -€7.8 billion prior
description:
• Prior -€7.8 billion; revised to -€7.6 billion

The French trade deficit holds almost unchanged on the month of June compared to May. That comes as exports were seen up 3.4% on the month while imports also rose by 2.9% on the month.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
patterns: Historically, a slight decrease in trade deficit has shown a minor positive impact on the economy. However, the effects are usually not immediate.
explanation: The French trade deficit for the month of June has been revised to -€7.6 billion from the prior -€7.8 billion. This indicates a minor improvement in the trade balance, which is a positive sign for the French economy. The slight decrease in the deficit suggests that France's exports have grown at a faster rate than its imports. In fact, exports were seen up by 3.4% on the month while imports rose by 2.9%. This could be a sign of increased competitiveness of French goods in international markets, or a reflection of changes in domestic consumption patterns. However, the impact on the economy is likely to be minor given the small magnitude of the change. Furthermore, it's important to note that this is a single data point and doesn't necessarily indicate a trend. title: Prices are going up in the terminal business, capacity is close to full - Maersk CEO
description:
• Container demand continues to be extraordinarily high
  • Chinese companies are taking global market share, underpinning demand
  • China continues to grow their exports at a much higher pace than its GDP growth
  • We have seen rising freight spot rates, they rose 37% in 13 weeks during Q2 2025

As the US and China trade truce holds for now, we can see that the impact has been reverberating for many months already even though the two countries struck an accord back in early May. And with shipping capacity being nearly fully utilised, it pushes freight charges higher amid the ongoing surge in demand/supply chain hit. The rush here is all to avoid any uncertainty that tariffs could come back any time. From a few months back: Tariffs policy can change overnight but supply chains cannot

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
markets: Shipping, Logistics, Global Trade, China Market
patterns: Similar to the 2010-2011 container shipping boom, where high demand and limited capacity led to increased freight rates.
explanation: This news indicates a bullish sentiment for the terminal business, particularly for companies like Maersk. The high demand for containers, driven by Chinese companies taking significant global market share, is causing a surge in prices. This is further supported by China's exports growing at a faster rate than its GDP, indicating a strong demand for goods. The shipping capacity is near saturation, which is driving freight charges higher. This is similar to supply-demand dynamics that drive up prices in any market. The uncertainty regarding tariffs also adds to the rush, as businesses seek to avoid potential costs. This environment creates a positive outlook for shipping companies as they can leverage the high demand and limited capacity to increase their revenues. However, it's important to note that this could lead to inflationary pressures in the global economy, which could be a concern for central banks and policymakers.

title: Japan slashes growth forecast amid drag from US tariffs, feeble consumption activity
description:
The Japanese government has moved to cut its GDP growth forecast for the current fiscal year to 0.7%, down from the 1.2% estimate projected back in January. This comes as US tariffs could weigh on Japanese firms' appetite on capital expenditure as exports to the US will take a significant hit. Adding to that will be persistent concerns surrounding inflation that is expected to weigh further on domestic consumption.

Looking out to the next fiscal year though, the government is keeping a view that the economy will sustain a domestic-demand led recovery with wage growth poised to outpace inflation and help out with private consumption. They see GDP growth forecast picking up to 0.9% in the year after as such.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the US-China trade war impact on China's economic growth
explanation: The Japanese government's decision to cut its GDP growth forecast for the current fiscal year to 0.7% from the earlier projected 1.2% is a negative indicator for the Japanese economy. This is primarily due to the impact of US tariffs, which are expected to significantly affect Japanese firms' capital expenditure and exports to the US. Additionally, concerns about inflation are expected to further dampen domestic consumption. However, the government expects a recovery led by domestic demand in the next fiscal year, with wage growth expected to outpace inflation and boost private consumption. Despite this, the overall impact is negative as the immediate outlook is bearish due to the downward revision of the GDP growth forecast and the potential impact of US tariffs and inflation on the economy.

title: Is the Fed about to make another policy mistake?
description:
Since the softer than expected NFP report, Fed members started to line up for a September cut. Overall, the data wasn’t as bad as one might think by just looking at the reaction but given that we were positioned for a strong report and the pricing got more hawkish after the Fed’s decision, the weaker data was enough to trigger a quick repricing.

In fact, the market is now pricing 60 bps of easing by year-end compared to just 35 bps before the NFP release. The pricing got also solidified by several Fed members opening the door for an imminent cut. We had Fed's Williams, Fed's Daly and Fed's Kashkari all citing labour market weakness as the reason for pre-emptively cut.

Just before the NFP report, they were saying that they want to balance both sides of the mandate and that price stability was the one requiring more attention given that we are still much closer to 3% than their 2% target. Nonetheless, it took just one soft NFP to trigger a quick change of heart. Where's the "rate cut at the next meeting will be decided by totality of the data leading up to it" gone?

I understand the market reacting and pricing expectations based on a single data point (that's normal), but the Fed is overreacting much like the market, which could set them up for a policy mistake. If the labour market is actually fine and they cut, then there's a high chance they will cut into a rebounding economy and increase the momentum.

We all know that tariff uncertainty kind of froze the labour market and other investments. That is now old news. We have certainty now about the tariffs and so on, and that could see businesses getting back to hire and invest more, especially with higher rate cut probabilities.

The US jobless claims have been showing a "low firing, low hiring" labour market and surveys like the PMIs have been citing high inflationary pressures. We still have jobless claims today and CPI next week that could change market's expectations. Strong data is likely to trigger a more hawkish repricing, while weak data will reinforce bets for rate cuts and the probabilities for a third might increase further.

If the Fed continues with its dovish rhetoric despite stronger data just because of the NFP though, watch the 10 year Treasury yield as that will show you if the market is fearing a policy mistake. In fact, even if the Fed cuts, yields will likely rise (contrary to Trump's thinking) as the market will price in a higher inflation premium.

This article was written by Giuseppe Dellamotta at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the Fed's unexpected rate cut in July 2019, which led to market volatility and increased fears of a policy mistake.
explanation: The article suggests that the Federal Reserve may be on the brink of making a policy mistake by considering an interest rate cut. This is due to the softer than expected Non-Farm Payroll (NFP) report, which has led to some Fed members advocating for a cut. The market is now pricing 60 basis points of easing by year-end, up from 35 basis points before the NFP release. However, the article argues that the Fed may be overreacting to a single data point, and if the labour market is in fact healthy, a rate cut could lead to the Fed cutting into a rebounding economy, potentially leading to increased momentum. This could result in a policy mistake. The writer also suggests that if the Fed continues with its dovish rhetoric despite stronger data, it could lead to fears of a policy mistake, which could be reflected in the 10-year Treasury yield. Overall, this could lead to increased market volatility and uncertainty, particularly in the financial sector.

title: investinglive European FX news wrap: BoE delivers a hawkish cut
description:
• There was a chance the BOE decision today could've turned out really weird
  • US Bessent: Trade deals are largely done
  • BOE cuts bank rate by 25 bps to 4.00% as expected in August policy decision
  • Bitcoin rallies as Trump is set to allow cryptocurrencies in retirement plans
  • Japan prime minister Ishiba insists that there is no discrepancy on 15% tariffs rate
  • Equities continue to ramp higher as US data, tariff concerns are brushed aside
  • What to expect from the BOE policy decision coming up later?
  • Is the Fed about to make another policy mistake?
  • Japan slashes growth forecast amid drag from US tariffs, feeble consumption activity
  • Russia says that preparations for a Trump-Putin summit are already underway
  • China continues to snap up gold, reserves up for a ninth month in a row
  • Prices are going up in the terminal business, capacity is close to full - Maersk CEO
  • Dollar falls further on the week as the post-NFP fallout continues
  • France June trade balance -€7.6 billion vs -€7.8 billion prior
  • Eurostixx futures +0.5% in early European trading
  • UK July Halifax house prices +0.4% vs +0.3% m/m expected
  • Germany June trade balance €14.9 billion vs €17.3 billion expected
  • Germany June industrial production -1.9% vs -0.5% m/m expected
  • FX option expiries for 7 August 10am New York cut
  • Swiss Federal Council to hold extraordinary meeting as trade delegation returns from US
  • Trump says billions of dollars are flowing into the US as reciprocal tariffs take effect

It's been a pretty slow session in terms of data and news releases. We've got the usuall tariff news with the Japanese Prime Minister requesting that the US make amendments to its executive orders on tariffs for Japan. That as both sides are said to agree that the 15% tariffs rate is a ceiling, and not to be stacked on top of already existing levies.

We had also the confirmation that preparations for a Trump-Putin summit are already underway and that the two Presidents could meet in the coming days (likely next week). This will be the first time since June 2021 that we see a US president meet up with Russian president Putin.

Bitcoin rallied on the news that Trump will sign an executive order today to allow private equity, real estate, cryptocurrencies and other alternative assets in 401(K)s. The Bloomberg report said that the order would direct the Department of Labor to ease fiduciary restrictions that currently deter plan administrators from offering such products.

Finally, we got the BoE delivering a hawkish 25 bps cut today. It was the first time ever that the BOE had two rounds of voting to reach a majority decision on bank rate. The majority to cut was reached by just one vote. The statement also said that the restrictiveness of monetary policy has fallen as Bank Rate has been reduced. Inflation forecasts were also revised higher. The market is now seeing basically a 50% chance of another cut by year-end.

In the markets, the US dollar has been weak throughout the session but eventually erased some of the losses. Stock markets have been rallying steadily since yesterday and extended the gains today. Bond markets continue to range as we await the US jobless claims and the US CPI data.

This article was written by Giuseppe Dellamotta at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to previous instances where central banks have made unexpected decisions, the market tends to react with volatility. The announcement of cryptocurrencies being allowed in retirement plans also mirrors previous instances where regulatory changes have led to price rallies.
explanation: The news of the Bank of England (BoE) delivering a hawkish cut of 25 bps has likely caused some volatility in the forex market, particularly for the GBP. It's noteworthy that this was a majority decision reached by just one vote, indicating a division within the BoE. The inflation forecasts were also revised higher, suggesting potential future monetary policy changes. In the cryptocurrency market, Bitcoin's rally following the news of Trump's executive order allowing cryptocurrencies in retirement plans suggests a positive market sentiment towards regulatory acceptance of digital assets. Meanwhile, the equities market appears to be brushing aside tariff concerns, with stocks continuing to rally. This could be due to a combination of factors, including positive US data and the anticipation of a Trump-Putin summit. title: GBPUSD runs higher after rate cut. Buyers are more in control. Here are the reasons why.
description:
The Bank of England cut its benchmark rate by 25 basis points today, but the decision revealed a more divided committee than expected. The final vote was 5–4 in favor of the cut, a more hawkish outcome than the 7–2 split anticipated by markets.

In a rare move, the MPC required a second round of voting to reach a decision. The initial vote saw four members favor a 25 bp cut, four vote for no change, and one member—BoE's Taylor—supporting a 50 bp cut. Taylor ultimately shifted his vote to 25 bps in the second round, giving the majority needed to implement the reduction.

Governor Andrew Bailey reiterated that while inflation and growth risks remain elevated, the rate path has become more uncertain. He emphasized that policy is still restrictive, and warned against cutting too quickly or too deeply. Bailey also pointed to softer-than-expected pay growth in May and signs that businesses are delaying investment decisions.

Deputy Governor Ramsden acknowledged that the persistence of UK inflation has surprised the MPC, noting the role of supply-side constraints and highlighting a wide 2–4% estimate range for the UK’s neutral rate. Other officials echoed concerns about weak activity growth, and downplayed the idea that rising borrowing costs reflect doubts about the BoE’s credibility.

Bailey dismissed recession fears, stating that his outlook hasn’t changed much since May, and clarified that the recent upward revision to 2025 GDP was driven by new data, not a shift in the committee’s broader economic view.

Technically, the GBPUSD extended its bullish momentum today, breaking decisively above the 38.2% retracement of the July 1–August 1 decline at 1.33865 and clearing a key swing area between 1.33607 and 1.3378 (highlighted by green circles on the chart). That zone, previously acting as resistance, has now turned into support following the Bank of England decision. The pair is also moving firmly above its 100-day moving average, currently at 1.33535, marking a significant shift in the near-term technical bias.

This breakout above multiple key levels — the 100-day MA, the swing area, and the 38.2% retracement — confirms a bullish technical reversal after a persistent downtrend since early July. The next major target lies at the 50% midpoint of the July–August move at 1.3463, which sits within a broader resistance zone between 1.3451 and 1.3467. A break and hold above this area would further strengthen the bullish outlook.

Taking a broader look at the daily chart below, the trend for the year before the recent decline from the July 1 high, has been to the upside. The price bottomed in January, and trended higher into July. The more recent price decline below the 100-day moving average put that trend into question, but the low price on the move to the downside since the July 1 high could not reach the 38.2% retracement of the longer term move up from January low.

That failure to extend below the 38.2% retracement kept the buyers in the long-term more in control and in play. The break back above the 100-day moving average yesterday and the run higher today solidified the buyers control.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to previous instances when Bank of England cut its benchmark rate, the GBPUSD typically experiences a bullish trend.
explanation: The article discusses the impact of the Bank of England's decision to cut its benchmark rate by 25 basis points on the GBPUSD. The decision was more divided than expected, with a final vote of 5-4 in favor of the cut. This hawkish outcome has led to an increase in the GBPUSD, with the currency pair breaking decisively above key levels. It is also moving firmly above its 100-day moving average, marking a significant shift in the near-term technical bias. The article suggests that this breakout confirms a bullish technical reversal after a persistent downtrend since early July. The Bank of England's decision has turned a previous resistance zone into support, strengthening the bullish outlook for the GBPUSD. The Bank's reassurances against recession fears and the upward revision of 2025 GDP also contribute to the bullish sentiment. Overall, the article suggests that the GBPUSD is likely to continue its upward trend in the near future.

title: US stocks move higher as they shrug off threats of tariffs. NASDAQ on pace for a record.
description:
The major US stock indices are opening higher as they shrug off the tariff threats to chips/semiconductors and instead focus on the re-shoring prospects.. They are also focused on the potential for peace in Ukraine/Russia.

Looking at the major indices:

  • Dow industrial average is up 141 points or 0.32% at 44335.47. Is up 38.84 points or 0.49% at 6376.29.
  • S&P index is up 38.84 points or 0.49% at 6376.29.
  • NASDAQ index up 174.61 points or 0.82% at 21341.50.

Apple shares have extended their rally this morning, following yesterday’s 5.1% surge after announcing a $100 billion investment in the U.S. and the launch of the American Manufacturing Program. Shares are currently up to .83%

Bank of America noted that iPhones could gain market share if competitors are subject to tariffs and Apple receives exemptions.

Nvidia (up 0.65% yesterday underperforming the NASDAQ) and other chipmakers like AMD after yesterday's decline ( -6.42% tumble) after earnings. also traded higher, shrugging off President Trump’s threat of 100% tariffs on semiconductors—investors seem to believe the tariffs will come with U.S.-friendly carveouts. Nvidia’s ongoing U.S. investment reinforces that view. Nvidia shares are currently up 1.97% while AMD shares are up 3.85%.

Meanwhile, Eli Lilly shares tumbled after its GLP-1 weight loss pill underwhelmed in late-stage trials, showing an average 12% weight loss versus Street expectations of 13–15%. The company still plans to file for FDA approval later this year, and reported strong earnings alongside raised guidance thanks to injectable GLP-1 drugs Zepbound and Mounjaro. The stock is currently down -14.06%.

Intel fell by up to 5% following sharp criticism from President Trump, who called on new CEO Lip-Bu Tan to resign, citing concerns over his ties to Chinese firms—an issue echoed by Senator Tom Cotton. Tan had only recently taken the helm in March to lead a turnaround of the embattled chipmaker. Shares have recovered and are down only -1.91% at $20.02 currently .

The NASDAQ index on pace for a record close above 21178.58.. The intraday high price from July 31 reached 21457.48. The high price today has reached 21399.41 so far.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
markets: US Stock Market, Tech, Semiconductors, Pharmaceuticals

explanation: The major US stock indices are showing a positive trend despite the looming threat of tariffs on chips and semiconductors. This is due to the market's focus on the potential for reshoring and peace in Ukraine/Russia. The NASDAQ index is particularly on track for a record close. Shares of Apple and Nvidia, key players in the tech sector, are up, indicating a positive sentiment among investors despite the tariff threats. The market seems to believe that these tariffs will come with U.S.-friendly carveouts. The rise of AMD shares also supports this view. However, not all sectors are doing well. Eli Lilly shares have fallen due to underwhelming results in late-stage trials of its weight loss pill. Intel shares also fell due to criticism from President Trump. However, overall, the market sentiment appears to be bullish.

title: Investors can’t afford to ignore the stagflation threat shadowing the market
description: Don’t get caught napping by the potential for renewed inflation pressures as the economy slows, warns a top Wall Street economist.
patterns: Similar to the stagflation period in the 1970s
explanation: The article suggests that there is a threat of stagflation looming over the market. Stagflation is a combination of stagnant economic growth and high inflation, a situation that is generally considered negative for the stock market, hence the negative impact score. In such a scenario, companies face higher costs, which can erode their profit margins, while consumers face higher prices, which can impact their purchasing power and thus, consumer spending, a major driver of the economy. This can lead to lower corporate earnings, which can negatively impact stock prices. Furthermore, during periods of high inflation, central banks often raise interest rates to combat inflation, which can increase borrowing costs and further slow economic growth. This can also lead to a sell-off in the bond market as existing bonds become less attractive compared to new ones issued at higher interest rates. Finally, commodities can also be affected as they can become more expensive due to inflation, which can impact companies that rely on these commodities for their operations.

title: Investors can’t afford to ignore the stagflation threat shadowing the market
description: Don’t get caught napping by the potential for renewed inflation pressures as the economy slows, warns a top Wall Street economist.
patterns: Similar to the stagflation period of the 1970s, where inflation rose while economic growth slowed.
explanation: The news suggests that there is a potential for stagflation, a situation in which inflation rates are high and economic growth slows down. This is a significant threat to the market as it could lead to reduced earnings for companies, which in turn could lead to a decrease in stock prices. Furthermore, high inflation could erode the real value of future cash flows, making investments less attractive. If the economy slows down, unemployment could increase, reducing consumer spending and further slowing down the economy. This could also lead to a decrease in demand for commodities, negatively affecting those markets. The warning comes from a top Wall Street economist, indicating a high level of confidence in the analysis. Investors need to be cautious and possibly adjust their portfolios to mitigate the potential risks.

title: Investors can’t afford to ignore the stagflation threat shadowing the market
description: Don’t get caught napping by the potential for renewed inflation pressures as the economy slows, warns a top Wall Street economist.
patterns: Similar to the 1970s stagflation period where slow growth and high inflation led to a significant market downturn.
explanation: The article suggests that the threat of stagflation, a situation characterized by slow economic growth and high inflation, could potentially impact the market. This combination is particularly damaging as it creates a difficult environment for businesses to thrive, leading to lower corporate earnings and, subsequently, lower stock prices. The warning comes from a top Wall Street economist, which adds credibility to the threat. Inflation pressures could be renewed as the economy slows down, which would result in increased costs for businesses and consumers alike. This would likely dampen consumer spending, a key driver of economic growth. Additionally, if the Federal Reserve responds to inflation by hiking interest rates, borrowing costs could increase, further hampering business investment and growth. The potential for such a scenario is likely to create uncertainty among investors, leading to increased market volatility and potentially significant losses. Therefore, the impact on the markets is expected to be bearish.

title: Geopolitics: Netanyahu says Israel intends to take control of all of Gaza
description:
Israel's Netanyahu says:

  • Israel intends to take control of all of Gaza
  • We want to hand it over to Arab forces that will govern Gaza properly.
  • We don't want to keep Gaza, we want a security perimeter
  • The expansion is needed to ensure Israel's security

The war has extended on Iran with humanitarian concerns being an issue. I'm not sure if the intended goal and the humanitarian concerns can coexist. War is ugly.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
markets: Global Stock Markets, Oil & Gas, Defense
patterns: This is similar to Israel's 2005 disengagement from Gaza, which led to a temporary increase in regional tensions and had a negative impact on global markets.
explanation: The announcement by Israel's Netanyahu regarding Israel's intention to take control of all of Gaza could lead to increased geopolitical tensions in the Middle East. This could potentially disrupt global markets, particularly oil and gas, as well as defense sectors, due to the potential for conflict escalation. The statement of handing over control to Arab forces that will govern Gaza properly indicates a potential shift in power dynamics, which could further destabilize the region. Moreover, the mention of a war extending on Iran raises additional concerns about broader regional instability. While it is mentioned that the expansion is needed for Israel's security, the humanitarian concerns raised indicate potential international backlash, which could further complicate the situation and negatively impact markets. Overall, this news is likely to introduce a degree of uncertainty and risk in the markets, leading to a bearish outlook.

title: Now that Trump’s newest tariffs are live, what it means for you — and which countries and sectors are next
description: The White House’s trade focus now shifts to drugs, chips, China and Mexico.
patterns: Similar to the 2018 US-China trade war, where tariffs led to a decrease in market confidence and overall economic slowdown.
explanation: The introduction of new tariffs by the Trump administration will likely have a negative impact on the mentioned sectors and countries. Tariffs increase the cost of imported goods, which can lead to price increases for consumers and decreased competitiveness for businesses that rely on these imports. Specifically, the focus on drugs and chips suggests a potential impact on the pharmaceutical and semiconductor sectors. For countries like China and Mexico, this could mean a decrease in exports to the US, potentially harming their economies. Additionally, tariffs tend to create uncertainty in the market, which can lead to decreased investor confidence and market volatility. Given these factors, the impact is likely to be negative and significant, hence the high confidence level.

title: Sentiment on stocks collapses the most since the February market top
description: Market strategists say the measure, considered a contrarian signal, could ultimately force traders to get back into the market.
patterns: Similar to the market sentiment collapse in February 2020, which led to a market correction.
explanation: The sentiment on stocks has reportedly collapsed to levels not seen since the market top in February. This is a significant bearish signal, indicating that investors are losing confidence in the market, which could lead to a sell-off. However, market strategists suggest that this could be a contrarian signal. In other words, when sentiment is overwhelmingly negative, it could be an indication that the market is oversold and due for a rebound. This is because when most investors are bearish, it means that most of the selling has already occurred, and the market could be set for a rebound as buyers re-enter the market. However, the timing of such a rebound can be unpredictable, and it's also possible that the negative sentiment could lead to further declines before a rebound occurs. Therefore, while this news is bearish in the short term, it could potentially lead to bullish outcomes in the long term if it results in an oversold market bouncing back.

However, the timing of such a rebound is uncertain and depends on a variety of factors, including economic data, corporate earnings, and geopolitical events. Therefore, while the impact of this news is bearish in the short term, it could potentially lead to bullish conditions in the future.

title: I plan to work until 80. Can I contribute to my IRA while taking RMDs?
description: “I contribute the max to my IRA every year.”
patterns: There is a general trend of people working later in life and wanting to continue contributing to their retirement accounts.
explanation: The individual's plan to work until age 80 and continue contributing to their IRA while taking Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs) is a personal financial decision and doesn't directly impact the broader markets. However, it does reflect a growing trend of people working later into life and wanting to continue building their retirement savings. This could potentially have broader implications for the financial services sector, particularly those companies that manage retirement accounts. They may need to adjust their offerings or advice to account for this trend. The IRS rules currently allow individuals to continue contributing to their IRA past age 70.5 as long as they have earned income, but they must also start taking RMDs at that age. The interplay between these rules can be complex, and individuals in this situation may require more financial advice or services.

title: I plan to work until 80. Can I contribute to my IRA while taking RMDs?
description: “I contribute the max to my IRA every year.”
patterns: Similar to other individuals planning for retirement, this person is looking at how to best contribute to their IRA while also taking RMDs.
explanation: The individual plans to work until 80 and contribute the maximum to their IRA each year. This is a personal financial decision and doesn't directly impact the broader market. However, it does highlight the importance of retirement planning and the use of IRAs and RMDs. Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs) are minimum amounts that a retirement plan account owner must withdraw annually starting with the year that he or she reaches 72. Even if someone is still working at 72 and beyond, they must start taking RMDs from their retirement accounts (excluding Roth IRAs). They can still contribute to their IRA if they have earned income. This situation is common for those who choose to work later in life and continue to contribute to their retirement savings while also beginning to withdraw from them.

title: I plan to work until 80. Can I contribute to my IRA while taking RMDs?

patterns: No specific historical events

However, it highlights a trend among older workers who choose to continue working and investing in their retirement accounts. The IRS allows individuals to contribute to their IRAs as long as they have earned income, regardless of age. However, once the individual reaches the age of 72, they are required to start taking RMDs from their IRA. These distributions could potentially increase the individual's taxable income, depending on the size of the distributions and other income. Therefore, this decision is more relevant to personal finance and tax planning strategies rather than the broader financial markets.

title: US 30 year fixed mortgage falls to 6.63% from 6.72% last week
description:
The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage moved from 6.72% to 6.63% in the current week (-9 basis points). Over that same period, the 10-year yield moved from 4.38% to 4.23% today (-15 basis points).

Looking at the chart of the 30-year mortgage, the low came in 2021 near 2.65%. The high was in October 2023 near 7.79%. What did that do to the average mortgage rate on $100,000?

  • At 2.65%, the monthly payment would've been at $402.69.
  • At 7.79% the monthly payment ballooned to $718.19.

At the current rate of 6.63%, the payment is $641.16. That represents a 59% or $238.47 increase versus the low in 2021.

The good news is that at the high rate, the payment would have been $315.50 higher per month or 78.4% from the low.

Either way at 6.63%, the monthly payment is still a healthy difference of $238 per 100,000 versus the lows. On the median sales price for existing homes in the US at $435,000, that would represent an increase payment of $1,037.35 per month. That's a big increase..

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the period following the 2008 financial crisis, when interest rates were raised to stabilize the economy.
explanation: The decrease in the 30-year fixed mortgage rate from 6.72% to 6.63% is a bearish signal for the real estate and banking sectors. This is because lower mortgage rates typically stimulate demand for home purchases, which can be beneficial for the real estate market. However, the current rate is significantly higher than the low of 2.65% in 2021, which means that monthly payments are still considerably higher than they were at that time. This could potentially deter some potential buyers and slow down the housing market. For banks and financial services, higher mortgage rates generally mean higher profits as they earn more interest on loans. Therefore, the decrease in rates could potentially impact their profitability. The fact that the rate is still higher than the 2021 low, however, means that they are still earning more than they were at that time, which could mitigate some of the impact. Overall, while the decrease is a positive development for potential home buyers, it could have negative implications for the real estate and banking sectors.

title: From cellphones to gift cards, Costco is finding ways to boost monthly sales as shoppers face more ‘trade-off decisions’
description: The warehouse retailer “constantly finds new assortments to drive excitement,” UBS analysts said.
patterns: Similar to Amazon's strategy of constantly introducing new product categories to keep consumer interest high and drive sales.
explanation: Costco's strategy of constantly finding new assortments to drive excitement is a positive move that can potentially boost monthly sales. It is a tactic similar to what other successful retailers like Amazon have used, where they constantly introduce new product categories to keep consumer interest high and drive sales. This approach helps in two ways. Firstly, it keeps the customer base engaged and interested, as there's always something new to look forward to. Secondly, it can help Costco attract a wider demographic of shoppers who might be interested in the new product categories. As shoppers face more 'trade-off decisions', meaning they are becoming more selective and value-conscious, having a variety of products to choose from can give Costco a competitive edge. However, the success of this strategy is contingent on Costco's ability to effectively manage its inventory and supply chain, and to ensure that the new product assortments resonate with its customer base.

title: USDCAD technicals: The USDCAD is caught between the moving averages
description:
The USDCAD remains directionless in the short term, trading within well-defined technical boundaries as market participants await a decisive break.

On the 4-hour chart above, price action this week has respected major moving average levels:

  • Tuesday’s high extended up to test the 100-day moving average, currently at 1.37954, where sellers leaned against resistance and held the line.

  • On the downside, today’s low briefly moved below the 100-bar moving average on the 4-hour chart, now at 1.37305, but buyers quickly stepped in, preventing further downside and halting the decline.

Between these two key MAs lies a notable swing area from 1.3749 to 1.3758 — a zone that has consistently drawn interest from both buyers and sellers. The pair is currently trading within this range, reflecting market indecision.

Key Technical Levels:

  • Support: 100-bar MA on the 4-hour chart – 1.37305

  • Resistance: 100-day MA – 1.37954

  • Neutral zone: Swing area – 1.3749 to 1.3758

Bottom Line: Just like USDJPY, USDCAD is stuck between moving average extremes. The battle between buyers and sellers continues within a tight range, with momentum likely to build only after a break either above the 100-day MA or below the 100-bar MA on the 4-hour chart. Until then, tactical trading within the range remains the theme.

Visit daily and often at www.investingLive.com.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the USDJPY situation, where the currency pair also found itself stuck between moving averages, creating a tight trading range.
explanation: The USDCAD currency pair is currently trapped between two key moving averages, creating a narrow trading range. On one side, sellers have held the line at the 100-day moving average, which currently sits at 1.37954. On the other side, buyers have stepped in to halt any further decline whenever the price dips below the 100-bar moving average on the 4-hour chart, currently at 1.37305. This tug-of-war between buyers and sellers has created a neutral zone, or swing area, between 1.3749 and 1.3758. This indicates a certain level of market indecision, as participants await a decisive break in either direction. Until such a break occurs, it is expected that the USDCAD will continue to trade within this range. This situation is similar to the recent price action observed in the USDJPY currency pair, which also found itself stuck between moving averages.

title: Is the economy as good as Wall Street says it is? Financial markets and data are telling different stories.
description: Strong second-quarter earnings have been led by financial and tech firms, but they’ve offered little evidence of robust consumer health.
patterns: The scenario is similar to the 2008 financial crisis where Wall Street continued to show positive signs despite the underlying economic issues.
explanation: The strong second-quarter earnings led by financial and tech firms could be misleading. While these sectors are performing well, they do not necessarily reflect the overall health of the economy. The article suggests that there is little evidence of robust consumer health, which is a significant concern. Consumer spending is a critical driver of economic growth, and if this is weak, it could potentially lead to slower growth or even a recession. Moreover, the disconnect between the financial markets and economic data could be an indication of potential market bubbles. When market prices are not supported by underlying economic fundamentals, it increases the risk of a market correction. Therefore, while Wall Street may be painting a rosy picture, the underlying economic data suggests caution.

title: Is the economy as good as Wall Street says it is? Financial markets and data are telling different stories.

This could be due to the fact that these sectors are not necessarily reflective of the consumer market, which is a significant component of the economy. Furthermore, the discrepancy between the financial markets and data might be hinting at potential overvaluations in these sectors, which could lead to a market correction. It is also possible that the strong earnings are a result of cost-cutting measures or other non-recurring items, rather than an increase in sales or market share. Therefore, while the strong earnings are a positive sign, they do not necessarily mean that the economy as a whole is doing well.

title: Good news for media companies is proving to be bad news for their stocks

Furthermore, the media and entertainment sector is currently facing significant challenges, including changing consumer behavior and increased competition. Despite the strong results, these broader sectoral issues could be weighing on investor sentiment and contributing to the weakness in these stocks. Therefore, even though the companies are performing well, the stocks are under pressure due to market dynamics and sectoral challenges.

title: Good news for media companies is proving to be bad news for their stocks
description: Warner Bros. Discovery reported strong results Thursday, but the stock extended its recent weakness. The same thing happened to Walt Disney’s stock the day before.
patterns: Historically, media companies have seen their stock prices dip despite reporting strong results. This is similar to what happened with Netflix in July 2021, when it reported better-than-expected Q2 earnings but saw its stock fall due to slower subscriber growth.
explanation: The recent reports from Warner Bros. Discovery and Walt Disney show a paradoxical trend in the stock market for media companies. Despite strong financial results, their stocks have extended recent weakness. This could be attributed to a variety of factors. Investors may be concerned about the future growth prospects of these companies in a post-pandemic world, where a return to normal could mean less demand for home entertainment. Additionally, the media sector is facing increasing competition and regulatory scrutiny, which could be affecting investor sentiment. Lastly, market dynamics and investor psychology also play a role. Sometimes, even if a company reports strong results, if they do not meet the inflated expectations of investors, the stock price can still fall. This phenomenon is not unique to media companies, but it seems to be particularly pronounced in this sector at present.

This could be due to a variety of factors such as concerns over future growth, increased competition, or changes in industry dynamics. The media sector is facing increasing competition from streaming platforms and changing consumer habits, which could be impacting investor confidence in traditional media companies. Furthermore, the market could be factoring in potential regulatory challenges and the impact of global economic uncertainty on these companies. Therefore, despite strong results, the stocks of these media companies are facing downward pressure, which is a bearish indication for the media and entertainment sector.

title: ‘Billions’ in Medicare waste? Read the fine print.

explanation: The news article suggests that the amount of 'waste, fraud, and abuse' in federal government spending, particularly in Medicare, is less than what some people claim. However, this could also mean less opportunity for private sector involvement in providing Medicare services, potentially negatively impacting the healthcare and insurance sectors. The impact is not expected to be significant as the investigation's findings are in line with previous investigations. It's also important to note that such investigations can lead to policy changes aimed at reducing waste, fraud, and abuse. Future investigations and policy changes will provide more clarity on the issue.

title: How options trading in Palantir, Uber and Fortinet offers clues to the stocks’ postearnings moves
description: Key market indicators currently point to more upside for the S&P 500.
patterns: Historically, options trading patterns have often been reliable indicators of post-earnings stock movements.
explanation: The article suggests that options trading in Palantir, Uber, and Fortinet could provide insights into the stocks' post-earnings moves. The trading of options can often indicate the market's expectations of a stock's future price movements. If a large number of investors are buying call options, this could signify that they expect the stock price to increase. Conversely, if many investors are purchasing put options, they may be anticipating a decrease in the stock price. While this method is not foolproof, it can often provide useful clues. In this case, the key market indicators are pointing to more upside for the S&P 500, which suggests that investors are optimistic about the future performance of these stocks. However, as with all forms of analysis, it is essential to consider other factors and not rely solely on options trading patterns.

title: Why Fortinet’s stock could see its worst drop on record
description: The cybersecurity company just shared that it’s 40% to 50% done with an upgrade cycle for firewalls — but some analysts think that limits future opportunities.
patterns: Similar to when Symantec completed its major antivirus upgrade cycle in 2010, which resulted in a significant drop in its stock price.
explanation: Fortinet’s announcement that it is 40% to 50% done with an upgrade cycle for firewalls could be interpreted as a negative signal for future growth. This is because once the upgrade cycle is complete, there may be a decrease in demand for their products as customers will have the latest versions and won't need to upgrade for a while. This could lead to a slowdown in sales and hence affect the company's revenue and profitability. Additionally, the completion of the upgrade cycle might limit the company's future opportunities to generate additional revenue from the same customer base. In the past, similar situations have led to significant drops in stock prices for companies in the tech sector. Therefore, this news could potentially lead to a significant drop in Fortinet's stock price, making it a bearish signal for investors.

patterns: Similar to the situation with Symantec in 2017 when they announced they were halfway through their product upgrade cycle, causing a drop in stock prices due to perceived limited future growth.
explanation: The announcement from Fortinet that they are 40% to 50% done with an upgrade cycle for firewalls is likely to have a negative impact on their stock. This is because it signals that the company's growth may be limited in the future. When a company is in the midst of an upgrade cycle, it typically sees a boost in sales as customers upgrade to the latest product. However, once the cycle is completed, sales often decline as the market becomes saturated with the latest product. Therefore, being halfway through the cycle could indicate that Fortinet's growth may slow in the near future. This could result in a decrease in stock prices, as investors often look for companies with strong growth prospects. This situation is similar to what happened with Symantec in 2017, which saw a drop in stock prices after announcing they were halfway through their product upgrade cycle.

title: AUDUSD Technicals: Market trapped in a messy range between moving averages and swing zones
description:
Blur your eyes and look at the price action for the AUDUSD, and you see a lot of ups-and-downs. Since mid-April, the price has been mostly between 0.6354 and 0.6594.

Yes, two weeks ago, the price moved to a new high but stalled at a topside trend line. The buyers had their shot to break the ceiling and then the topside trend line, and they missed.

Sellers last week moved down from that high with the price moving back below the 100 and 200 bar MAs on the 4-hour chart (blue and green lines) on its way to the 100-day MA (blue line at 0.64326).

The price at the lows last week and near that key daily MA, did extend below the 100-day MA, but the weaker US jobs report stopped that idea, and the price moved back higher.

This week, the price low for the week bottomed near the low from July 17 at 0.64519. The price moved higher and traded today above both the 100-bar MA (0.65109) and the 200-bar MA (0.6526), but stalled near the swing area (green numbered circles).

The price has moved back down and below the MAs. Buyers had their shot, sellers are back in control.

Admittedly, it is a mess with all the ups and downs. However, if there are levels to watch I would focus on:

  • 0.6354 on the downside

  • 0.6594 on the topside

Those are the high and low extremes that if broken, the price is getting out of this up-and-down quagmire (it has to stay outside).

In between, the trader focus should be on:

  • 0.6436 – 100-day MA

  • 0.6452 – Swing low this week and from July 17

Those are targets for more selling.

On the topside:

  • 0.65109 – 100-bar MA on the 4-hour chart

  • 0.6526 – 200-bar MA on the 4-hour chart

  • 0.6536 – Swing area high (green line)

For your trading (and it is a trader’s market), those are the levels that will give clues for bias, risk, and targets.

What now? The buyers had their shot today and stalled at the swing area, then fell below the 200 and 100-bar MAs. If the sellers are to keep control, they could now use the 100-bar or 200-bar MAs as risk. Staying below would have traders targeting the low for the week.Visit daily and often at www.investingLive.com.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: The AUDUSD currency pair has been trapped in a similar range in the past, with significant ups and downs but ultimately remaining within a certain price range.
explanation: The AUDUSD market has been fluctuating significantly since mid-April, with the price mostly between 0.6354 and 0.6594. Despite attempts by buyers to break the ceiling, they have been unsuccessful. Sellers, on the other hand, have managed to bring the price down, with the price moving back below the 100 and 200 bar MAs on the 4-hour chart. The price has moved back down and below the MAs, indicating that sellers are back in control. However, the market is currently in a messy state, with lots of ups and downs. While it's difficult to predict the future direction of the market, the key levels to watch are 0.6354 on the downside, 0.6594 on the topside, and 0.6436 and 0.6452 in between. These levels will provide clues for bias, risk, and targets.

title: Is now a good time to refinance your car loan? Here’s how to tell.
description: As Americans’ car-loan balances increased in the second quarter, data suggests nearly a quarter of borrowers could save on their monthly payment or reduce their total interest by refinancing.
patterns: Similar to 2008 financial crisis, when many people refinanced their loans to save money.
explanation: The news indicates that a significant portion of American car loan borrowers could potentially save on their monthly payments or reduce their total interest by refinancing their car loans. This is a result of an increase in car loan balances in the second quarter. Refinancing can be a beneficial move for borrowers when interest rates are low, as it can lower their monthly payments and overall interest. It suggests that the auto and banking sectors could see increased activity as more people look into refinancing options. However, it's also important to note that while refinancing can save money in the short term, it can also extend the life of the loan, which may result in paying more interest over time. Therefore, while this news is somewhat positive, the impact is not expected to be significantly bullish.

explanation: The increase in car-loan balances indicates a potential surge in the auto market as more people are able to afford cars. Refinancing could lead to a decrease in interest income for banks, but it could also mean lower default rates as borrowers find it easier to manage their payments. Thus, this could be a mixed signal for the banking and finance sector. For the auto sector, increased car-loan balances could mean higher sales in the short term. However, if a significant number of people choose to refinance, it could indicate a lack of confidence in the economy, which could negatively impact future auto sales.

title: Credit-card debt declines for second straight month in June
description: U.S. consumers are pulling back on spending.
patterns: Similar patterns were observed during the 2008 recession, where consumers also pulled back on spending due to economic uncertainty.
explanation: The decline in credit-card debt for the second straight month in June suggests that U.S. consumers are becoming more cautious about their spending. This could be due to a variety of factors including economic uncertainty, job insecurity, or a desire to save more. This pullback in consumer spending can have a negative impact on the retail and consumer goods sectors, as less spending means less revenue for these businesses. Additionally, financial services could also be affected as they earn interest from credit card debts. If consumers are reducing their credit card debts, it means they are borrowing less, which could lead to lower interest income for these companies. This news is bearish as it indicates potential slowdown in consumer spending which can affect economic growth. The high confidence level is due to the clear correlation between consumer spending and economic health.

Investors should continue to monitor the situation for any changes that could affect their portfolios.

title: What’s at stake for oil prices ahead of Trump’s Friday deadline for Russia-Ukraine cease-fire
description: Investors may soon find out just how willing President Donald Trump is to punish Russia in the face of a potential jump in oil prices, as a Friday deadline set by the White House for a cease-fire with Ukraine looms over the market.
patterns: Similar to the 2014 Crimea crisis where Russia's intervention led to international sanctions and consequently a surge in oil prices.
explanation: The potential of President Trump imposing sanctions on Russia due to its conflict with Ukraine could have significant bearish implications for the oil market. If a cease-fire is not established by the Friday deadline set by the White House, the U.S. may respond with punitive measures against Russia, a major global oil producer. Such measures could disrupt Russia's oil production or exports, leading to a decrease in global oil supply and consequently an increase in oil prices. This would negatively impact oil-dependent industries and economies, thus leading to a decrease in global economic activity. Furthermore, the uncertainty surrounding the situation may cause investors to shift their investments away from oil and other commodities, further depressing prices. Given the high stakes and the potential for significant market disruption, the confidence level of this analysis is high.

title: Bloomberg:White House prepares for US Pres. Trump to nominate CEA Chair Miran to Fed board
description:
Bloomberg is reporting that the White House is preparing for US Pres. Trump to announce CEA Chair Stephen Miran to become the temporary Fed Board member replacing Adriana Kugler.

UPDATE: Trump now announces that Miran will be taking Kuglers seat until January 31, 2026.

Who is Stephen Miran?

  • Current Role: Stephen Miran has served as Chair of the Council of Economic Advisers since March 2025. He was confirmed by the Senate in a 53–46 vote.

  • Education: He holds a Ph.D. in Economics from Harvard University and a B.A. from Boston University in economics, philosophy, and mathematics.

  • Professional Background: Miran has worked as a senior strategist at a hedge fund, a senior fellow at a policy think tank, and served as a senior advisor at the U.S. Treasury during the first Trump administration. He was involved in designing and executing emergency fiscal support during the pandemic and received recognition for exceptional service.

  • Research & Focus Areas: His work has examined household savings, tariffs, debt issuance, and global monetary dynamics. He is a critic of the overvaluation of the U.S. dollar and supports the use of tariffs to adjust trade balances.

Economic Philosophy & Policy Views

  • Deregulation: Miran views deregulation as a key tool to lower business costs and combat inflation by expanding supply and reducing compliance burdens.

  • Trade Policy: He supports tariffs and protectionist measures as a way to correct structural trade imbalances, challenging the mainstream view that all protectionism is harmful.

  • Federal Reserve Reform: He has expressed concern about the level of independence at the Federal Reserve and believes more accountability is needed, especially when monetary policy decisions have major economic and political implications.

Today on Bloomberg:

Miran said today:

  • There is virtually no inflationary pressures from the tariffs.
  • If there were to have a price impact it would be a one-time price increase
  • In the short run there can be price volatility. It is a short-run price adustment.
  • Thinks GOv. Waller has built up a really good track record on inflation and not succumbing to tariff inflation threat.
This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to when Jerome Powell was nominated as Fed Chair, markets reacted positively to a familiar face with a clear policy stance.
explanation: The announcement of Stephen Miran's nomination to the Fed board by President Trump is likely to have a modestly positive impact on the financial markets. Miran's support for deregulation and his views on combating inflation by expanding supply and reducing compliance burdens are generally seen as business-friendly and could lead to a positive reaction in the stock market, particularly in the financial sector. His criticism of the overvaluation of the U.S. dollar and support for tariffs to adjust trade balances could potentially impact the currency markets. His stance on Federal Reserve reform, calling for more accountability, could also introduce an element of predictability in monetary policy decisions. However, it's worth noting that these are potential impacts and the actual effect on the markets will depend on a variety of factors including the broader economic environment and the response of other Fed board members.

title: Financial Times: US hits one-kilo gold bars with tariffs
description:
Reuters with the headlines that the Financial Times is splashing news on gold tariffs - that the US hits one-kilo gold bars with tariffs

  • US hits one-kilo gold bars with tariffs in blow to refining hub Switzerland
  • US Customs Border Protection agency said one-kilo and 100 ounce gold bars should be classified under a customs code subject to levies

The Financial Times is gated. In brief:

  • The United States has placed tariffs on imports of one-kilogram gold bars, the Financial Times reported Thursday, citing a letter from U.S. Customs and Border Protection.
  • Dated July 31, the letter stated that one-kilo and 100-ounce gold bars should be classified under a customs code that makes them subject to levies. According to the report, the change could affect Switzerland, the world’s largest gold refining centre.
This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the 2002 steel tariffs imposed by the United States, which led to increased domestic prices.
explanation: The United States has imposed tariffs on one-kilo gold bars, according to a report by the Financial Times. This move is likely to have a bearish impact on the gold market, as it could increase the cost of gold imports into the United States, potentially reducing demand. The tariffs could also have a significant impact on Switzerland, which is the world's largest gold refining center. Higher costs for gold imports could discourage U.S. businesses from sourcing their gold from Switzerland, potentially hurting the Swiss economy. Furthermore, if the tariffs lead to a decrease in the global demand for gold, this could depress global gold prices, negatively affecting gold producers and investors. This situation is similar to the 2002 steel tariffs imposed by the United States, which led to increased domestic prices and strained trade relations. Therefore, this news is expected to have a bearish impact on the gold market, with a high level of confidence.

title: Crocs’ stock has its worst day in 14 years. People want discounts or they won’t buy.
description: Crocs’ stock tumbles as cautious consumer, reduced discounting and a trend toward athletic apparel leads to a weak sales outlook.
patterns: This situation is reminiscent of the 2008 financial crisis when consumer discretionary spending significantly dropped, leading to a fall in stocks of many retail companies.
explanation: The stock of Crocs, a leading footwear company, has experienced its worst day in 14 years due to a combination of factors. First, the cautious consumer spending indicates a potential decrease in disposable income, which directly impacts retail sectors, especially those dealing with non-essential items like footwear. Secondly, the company's decision to reduce discounting might have led to a decrease in sales, as customers are more likely to buy if they perceive a bargain. Lastly, the current trend towards athletic apparel suggests a shift in consumer preference, which Crocs may not be able to cater to with their existing product line. All these factors contribute to a weak sales outlook, which has negatively impacted the company's stock price. Given these circumstances, it is highly likely that the retail and footwear sectors will continue to experience bearish trends in the near future.

title: More nothingburger from Akazawa on Japan trade tariff talks with the US
description:
LOADS of words from Akazawa after extended talks, but nothing concrete at all.

  • Akazawa held talks with US Commerce Secretary Lutnick for 3 hours
  • Held talks Treasury Secretary Bessent for 30 minutes

And the big reveal from Akazawa is this load of nothing:

  • Both sides reaffirmed importance of steadily implementing measures that benefit interests of both Japan and US under Japan-US agreement
  • Strongly urged the US side to reconfirm agreement on reciprocal tariffs
  • Japan will continue to maintain close communication with the US side at various levels
  • Urged the US side to correct the executive order regarding reciprocal tariffs

That's him in the hat.

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to previous trade talks between the US and China where concrete decisions were not reached initially
explanation: The article reports on a recent round of trade talks between Japan and the US, led by Akazawa. Despite extended discussions with both the US Commerce Secretary and Treasury Secretary, no concrete decisions were made. Both sides reiterated their commitment to implementing measures that benefit both countries under the existing Japan-US agreement. Japan also urged the US to reconfirm the agreement on reciprocal tariffs and to correct the executive order regarding these tariffs. The lack of concrete outcomes from these talks suggests that uncertainty remains in the Japan-US trade relationship. This can potentially lead to market volatility, particularly in sectors related to trade and forex. However, the reaffirmation of commitment to mutual benefits suggests a willingness to maintain stable trade relations, which may mitigate potential negative impacts. Overall, the impact of this news is neutral, given the lack of concrete decisions and the continued commitment to mutual benefits.
