title: investingLive Asia-Pacific FX news wrap: US slammed strategic big gold bars with tariffs
description:
Japanese equities rose after Tokyo secured a U.S. pledge to correct a tariff order and refund excess duties, while the Bank of Japan’s July meeting summary revealed divisions over the timing of future rate hikes. The yen weakened, USD/JPY topping 147.30, as the dollar firmed slightly more broadly. The U.S. slapped tariffs on large gold bars, a move seen disrupting bullion market funding and strengthening COMEX’s role in price discovery.

  • Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President Alberto Musalem is speaking on Friday
  • Bank of England Chief Economist Huw Pill is speaking on Friday
  • Gold Breakout to Record High, Traders Got the Early Call from investingLive.com
  • More on the US tariff hits to strategic gold bars ... this could get real ugly, real fast
  • UBS has warned that U.S. tariffs on large gold bars could spark disruption
  • Reports Prime Minister Netanyahu’s proposal for the occupation of Gaza City approved
  • Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 index has jump 2% on he better news from Akazawa on tariffs
  • PBOC sets USD/ CNY reference rate for today at 7.1382 (vs. estimate at 7.1742)
  • Head of China's SMIC says demand still outstrips supply, rush orders to ease in Q4
  • Japanese trade envoy Akazawa reckons he's made progress in US trade talks (gets a refund!)
  • RBA tipped to cut rates to 3.60% in August (certainty this time!), more likely by year-end
  • Splits evident at Bank Japan on rate hike timing as inflation stays hot, trade risks loom
  • BoJ July policy meeting 'Summary" contains multiple references to heightened uncertainty
  • Japan data - June Household Spending +1.3% y/y (vs. expected +2.6%)
  • Tariff shock sends 2025 oil demand growth to less than half earlier forecasts
  • Bank of England tensions mount - Split BOE vote sets stage for more pound gains
  • Captain Obvious Bessent says Trump using tariffs as a foreign policy instrument
  • UBS love equites: Fundamentals to keep markets afloat as tariffs bite, Fed easing looms
  • Rabobank forecasts USD/CAD to trade in 1.34–1.36 range as US-Canada rate gap narrows
  • Financial Times: US hits one-kilo gold bars with tariffs
  • investingLive.com Americas FX news wrap 7 Aug: Trump taps Stephen Miran as Fed Govenor
  • TACO time - Trump says Putin doesn’t have to agree to meet with Zelenskiy to meet with me
  • Major US stock indices close mixed with the NASDAQ marginally higher

Japanese trade envoy Ryosei Akazawa said the U.S. has agreed to correct a presidential order on tariffs and refund any excess duties collected in error. He stressed there was no disagreement between the two countries over reciprocal tariffs.

  • Under the agreement, items previously taxed above 15% will now be capped at that rate, while those under 15% will be charged exactly 15%, including existing duties.
  • Akazawa called it “extremely regrettable” that the original order failed to reflect the agreed terms, but said U.S. officials expressed regret and pledged a timely correction.
  • Once amended, a new order will formalise the tariff rates agreed in July, including cutting U.S. auto tariffs from 27.5% to 15%.

Japanese equities rose on the news.

From the Bank of Japan, the July meeting “Summary of Opinions” — following the decision to keep the short-term rate at 0.5% — showed a lively debate over the timing of the next hike.

  • Several members said the BoJ is likely to keep raising rates if the economy and prices track forecasts, warning that waiting too long could force rapid tightening later. Others favoured holding the current accommodative stance for now, citing uncertainty around the bank’s projections.
  • Inflation concerns dominated, while trade and geopolitical risks were also in focus.

The yen eased through the session, with USD/JPY climbing to just over 147.30. The dollar was modestly firmer more broadly, though ranges were subdued.

Gold fell back from highs above US$3,405. The big story in bullion was the U.S. decision to impose tariffs on strategic large gold bars (1 kg and 100 oz) — the formats COMEX accepts for delivery. The move is expected to disrupt the Exchange for Physical mechanism linking London’s unallocated market to New York’s deliverable futures, forcing shorts to close or roll positions and potentially triggering a funding squeeze in London’s bullion banking system. By constraining deliverable supply, it accelerates Basel III-driven pressure on bullion banks to hold more physical metal and limits the LBMA’s ability to rehypothecate bars, denting Switzerland’s refining dominance and boosting COMEX’s role in global price discovery. More details in the somewhat posts.

In geopolitics, Israel said it will retake Gaza City, escalating the conflict with Hamas.

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to past instances of trade disputes causing market volatility, such as the US-China trade war.
explanation: The news article is primarily focused on the imposition of US tariffs on large gold bars, which is expected to disrupt the bullion market funding and strengthen COMEX’s role in price discovery. This could lead to a decline in gold prices, making it bearish for the gold market. Moreover, the Japanese equities market responded positively to the US pledge to correct a tariff order and refund excess duties, which is bullish for the Japanese equities market. The forex market also saw some movement with the yen weakening against the dollar. However, the Bank of Japan's division over future rate hikes adds uncertainty to the market. Overall, while there are some positive aspects, the disruption in the gold market and uncertainty in forex make the overall impact slightly bearish.

title: Gold spot prices hold steady despite surge in COMEX futures, what's next?
description:
The surprise tariffs is clearly catching the market off guard as we see a surge now in COMEX futures as compared to their counterpart in London. Essentially with the tariffs now, it just means that gold will be more expensive in the US market as opposed to overseas markets.

And that is leading to the uncommon price discrepancy we're seeing with regards to the price futures between the COMEX and LME. In a typical scenario, the prices should only differ due to contract specifications - which are backed by the physical delivery of the underlying metal.

But before any gold is transported to the US from London, it has to go through refineries in Switzerland to be recast. That is due to COMEX requiring different bar sizing for their contracts. Then only is the gold transported to the US for physical delivery. Hence, that is where the tariffs come in and making it more expensive for gold prices in the US now. That as well as Switzerland also refines roughly 90% of gold sourced from industrial mines.

So, what's next for gold prices if this is the case?

The thing to note is that markets were not quite prepared for this tariffs announcement. The gold rush into the US that we saw back in January and February didn't quite continue and now markets are left with their heads in their hands for the most part.

In turn, that could lead to a potential funding stress that UBS warns here. It's a good read if you haven't gotten to it earlier to understand what the potential ramifications of the tariffs could be.

But at least for now, gold lease rates have yet to surge amid the latest developments. The 1-month forward is roughly at -0.18% as opposed to the start of the year eruption to a whopping 5%. (h/t @ zerohedge)

This suggests that there is good amount of supply of gold in London for the time being.

How does this impact the spot price?

For now, prices are steady with not too much movement. Gold is hovering around $3,392 even as COMEX futures are surging. I reckon traders are taking their time to evaluate the whole situation and we haven't seen any major alarm just yet.

But at the end of it all, it comes down to what the US is actually trying to do here. Is this just a technicality gone wrong or is this intentional?

The Trump administration will have to clarify this ruling letter, even if it was issued by the Customs Border Protection agency. At this point, only Trump's words should be taken as confirmation really. But if the letter does hold, then what exactly is the US trying to do here?

For one, it might be a play to try and bump up Treasury reserves. In other words, a basic case of revaluing gold held by the US Treasury and solidifying a better position for themselves. If so, we could see spot prices explode further in keeping with the tailwinds that have underpinned gold all through the year.

I mean, it wouldn't be too farfetched to say that this move is done to drive up demand amid choking the so-called gold "supply chain". This would lead to prices moving up as paper shorts get burned. And once the market settles down and reprice everything at a higher level, the US then gets to work with a more golden benchmark that sees it trump above everyone else.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the 2008 financial crisis, where gold prices surged due to economic uncertainty.
explanation: The surprise tariffs have led to a surge in COMEX futures, making gold more expensive in the US market compared to overseas markets. This has resulted in an unusual price discrepancy between the COMEX and LME. Before gold is transported to the US from London, it has to go through refineries in Switzerland to be recast, due to COMEX requiring different bar sizing for their contracts. This is where the tariffs come into play, making it more expensive for gold prices in the US. However, despite this development, gold spot prices have remained steady. Traders are likely taking their time to evaluate the situation. The US's intentions behind these tariffs are unclear. If the intention is to revalue gold held by the US Treasury and solidify a better position for themselves, we could see spot prices increase further. This move could drive up demand while choking the gold supply chain, leading to higher prices and a more valuable benchmark for the US.

title: ‘Stagflation is coming to the U.S.,’ says this economist. Here’s what it means for the dollar, bonds and stocks.
description: The greenback faces a Wile E. Coyote moment says Savvas Savouri
patterns: Similar to the stagflation period of the 1970s in the United States, where the economy experienced stagnant growth, high inflation and high unemployment.
explanation: The prediction of stagflation coming to the U.S. implies a period of stagnant economic growth combined with high inflation and unemployment. This scenario is generally bearish for the dollar, bonds, and stocks. In such an environment, the value of the dollar could decrease due to inflation, making imports more expensive and potentially exacerbating inflation further. For bonds, inflation erodes the real value of the fixed interest payments that bondholders receive. Therefore, in a stagflation environment, bond prices might decline as investors demand higher yields to compensate for the increased inflation risk. Stocks could also be negatively affected as companies' costs rise due to inflation, squeezing profit margins. Lower corporate profits can lead to a decline in stock prices. However, the confidence level is set to medium as economic predictions can be uncertain and depend on a variety of factors not mentioned in the article.

title: ‘Stagflation is coming to the U.S.,’ says this economist. Here’s what it means for the dollar, bonds and stocks.
description: The greenback faces a Wile E. Coyote moment says Savvas Savouri
patterns: Similar to the 1970s stagflation in the U.S. where inflation and unemployment rose simultaneously while the economy stagnated.
explanation: Stagflation, a situation where inflation and unemployment rise while economic growth stagnates, is a potentially damaging scenario for the U.S. economy. Savvas Savouri's prediction of a 'Wile E. Coyote' moment for the greenback implies a sharp fall after a period of suspended reality. This could result in a weaker dollar, which might lead to higher import costs and thus, increased inflation. In the bond market, stagflation is generally negative as it erodes the value of fixed income payments. For stocks, the impact could be mixed. While some sectors may benefit from inflation (such as commodities), others may suffer due to higher input costs and lower consumer spending. Overall, the impact of this news is bearish for the markets mentioned. The confidence level is high given Savouri's reputation as an economist and the logic behind the prediction.

title: India reportedly pauses plans to buy US arms as trade dispute rages on
description:
Reuters is reporting on the matter and the sources cited also say that India's defence minister has cancelled his planned visit to the US. This comes as India is now pausing plans to purchase US arms, which would've included Boeing P-8I aircrafts, Stryker vehicles, and Javelin missiles.

It is said that India is now waiting on more clarity on US tariffs and trade developments before thinking about resuming arms purchase discussions. On trying to find a compromise, India is reported to be open to reducing oil imports from Russia as part of any tariffs settlement. But for now, we'll have to wait and see if there is any common ground to work with after things have gone south rather quickly in the past few weeks.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to instances where geopolitical tensions or trade disputes have disrupted arms deals, such as the US-Turkey dispute over the S-400 missile system.
explanation: This news is bearish for the US defense and aerospace sectors, particularly for companies like Boeing, who were set to provide aircrafts as part of the arms deal. The suspension of the deal not only directly impacts these companies' potential revenues, but also signals a deterioration in US-India trade relations. India's willingness to reduce oil imports from Russia as part of a tariff settlement also suggests that the dispute is affecting a broader range of sectors. Furthermore, the cancellation of the Indian defence minister's visit to the US indicates a serious escalation of the situation. While it's still uncertain how this will play out, the immediate impact is negative for US defense and aerospace companies. Additionally, this development could potentially affect the broader market if it leads to increased trade tensions between the US and India.

title: USDCAD technicals: The weaker Canada jobs report has pushed the USDCAD higher. What next?
description:
The USDCAD has moved modestly higher after the weaker than expected Canadian jobs report.

  • Employment Change:

    • Actual: -40.8k

    • Expected (Reuters Poll): +13.5k

    • Prior: +83.1k

    • ? Major miss – Canada lost jobs instead of gaining as expected.

  • Unemployment Rate:

    • Actual: 6.9%

    • Expected: 7.0%

    • Prior: 6.9%

    • ? Slightly better than expected, holding steady.

  • Full-Time Employment Change:

    • Actual: -51.0k

    • Prior: +13.5k

    • ? Big drop – full-time jobs took the biggest hit.

  • Part-Time Employment Change:

    • Actual: +10.3k

    • Prior: +69.5k

    • ? Minor gain, but not enough to offset full-time losses.

  • Participation Rate:

    • Actual: 65.2%

    • Prior: 65.4%

    • ? Lower participation, showing reduced engagement in the labor force.

Summary:

Canada’s July jobs report was significantly weaker than expected, with a net loss of 40.8k jobs driven by a sharp decline in full-time positions. While the unemployment rate held steady and was slightly better than forecast, the overall data paints a picture of labor market softness, with a declining participation rate and a reversal from strong prior job gains.

Technically, the USDCAD pair moved modestly higher but into resistance. In the video above I take a look at the technicals that are driving the pair and explain why. There have been some key support and resistance levels that has defined the trading range not only for the day but for the week.

Traders/investors will be using those levels to define the bias, define the risks, and define the targets.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Historically, weaker than expected jobs reports tend to negatively impact the local currency, leading to a rise in currency pairs like USDCAD.
explanation: The Canadian jobs report for July was significantly weaker than expected, with a net loss of 40.8k jobs. This was primarily due to a sharp decline in full-time positions. The unemployment rate, while steady and slightly better than forecast, does not counterbalance the overall picture of labor market softness painted by the other data. The participation rate has declined, indicating reduced engagement in the labor force. This negative labor market data has led to a modest rise in the USDCAD pair. However, this pair has moved into resistance, which may limit further gains. Traders and investors will be closely watching the key support and resistance levels that define the trading range for the pair. This data is likely to influence trading decisions, with potential to further impact the USDCAD market in the short term.

title: Trump warns courts against knocking down tariffs, says duties are 'huge positive' for stock market
description: The president said such a move could cause a Great Depression-style economic situation.
patterns: Similar to the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 which led to a massive contraction in global trade
explanation: President Trump's statement that tariffs are a 'huge positive' for the stock market can have a dual impact. On one hand, tariffs can be seen as a positive as they protect domestic industries from foreign competition, potentially boosting profits for these companies and, by extension, their stock prices. On the other hand, tariffs can also escalate into trade wars, which can have a negative impact on the global economy. This can lead to a decrease in international trade and potentially a recession, which would negatively impact the stock market. Furthermore, the president's warning against courts knocking down tariffs introduces uncertainty into the market, which can also have a negative impact on stock prices. Therefore, while there may be some short-term positive impacts, the long-term impacts of tariffs on the stock market are uncertain and potentially negative.

Moreover, they can lead to trade wars, as other countries may retaliate with their own tariffs. This could result in a slowdown in global trade, which would negatively affect the stock market. The President's comparison of a potential tariff knockdown to a Great Depression-style economic situation also adds to the bearish sentiment. During the Great Depression, the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act exacerbated the situation by severely restricting international trade. Therefore, the news could potentially have a negative impact on the S&P 500, Dow Jones, and NASDAQ markets.

title: Millions of student-loan borrowers have no idea how much they’re supposed to pay
description: Balances increasing, forgiveness paused — the “level of confusion is just crazy.”
patterns: Similar to the 2008 financial crisis when there was a high level of confusion about mortgage payments and balances.
explanation: The news indicates a high level of confusion among student loan borrowers about their repayment obligations. This could potentially lead to a significant number of defaults, which would negatively impact the financial services sector, particularly those companies involved in student lending. In addition, if borrowers are unable to make their payments, this could further exacerbate the economic difficulties already faced by many due to the pandemic. The pause in loan forgiveness could also contribute to increasing balances, adding to the financial burden on borrowers. This situation is reminiscent of the 2008 financial crisis when many homeowners were confused about their mortgage obligations, leading to widespread defaults and a significant economic downturn. Therefore, this news is bearish for the education and financial services sectors.

Additionally, the confusion among borrowers suggests that they may be unprepared to resume payments once the current loan forgiveness programs are paused, exacerbating the potential for defaults. This could have a knock-on effect on the consumer discretionary sector. If a significant number of people default on their loans, their credit scores could be impacted, reducing their ability to access credit for discretionary spending. This could lead to a decrease in consumer spending, negatively impacting companies in the consumer discretionary sector.

title: US/Russian officials are working toward an agreement on territories for summit
description:
There are reports:

  • US/Russia plan truce deal to cement Putins the gains in Ukraine
  • US and Russia are working toward an agreement on territories for a planned summit meeting as early as next week.
  • Russia would halt its offensive in the Kerson and Zaporizhzhia regions of Ukraine along the current battle lines as part of the deal.

The person left out is Zelenskiy who is on the outside looking in. This will likely not please the EU who have wanted to be part of the deal.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
markets: US Dollar, Russian Ruble, European Stocks, Energy Sector
patterns: Similar to the Minsk agreements in 2014 and 2015, which temporarily halted the conflict in Ukraine, but led to economic sanctions on Russia.
explanation: The news of a potential truce deal between the US and Russia over Ukraine is likely to have mixed impacts on financial markets. On one hand, the halt of Russia's offensive in Ukraine could ease geopolitical tensions, which may be positive for the Russian Ruble and European stocks. However, the exclusion of Zelenskiy and the EU from the deal could potentially lead to further political complications and uncertainty, which may negatively impact the market. Furthermore, any deal that cements Putin's gains in Ukraine could potentially lead to further international sanctions on Russia, which would likely weigh on the Russian economy and currency. The energy sector could also be affected, as Russia is a major global energy supplier, and any changes in the geopolitical situation could impact energy prices and stocks. Overall, the impact of this news is slightly bearish due to the potential for increased political uncertainty and the potential for further sanctions on Russia.

title: Sweetgreen shares drop 25% after salad chain cuts outlook for the second time in two quarters
description: Sweetgreen said it saw issues with its loyalty program, weak consumer sentiment, tariff headwinds and store challenges.
patterns: The situation is reminiscent of Chipotle's 2016 E.coli outbreak, where the company's stock plummeted after it had to shut down several stores.
explanation: Sweetgreen's shares have fallen by 25% after the salad chain cut its outlook for the second time in two quarters. This is a significant bearish indicator as it suggests that the company is struggling to meet its financial targets. The company cited issues with its loyalty program, weak consumer sentiment, tariff headwinds, and store challenges as reasons for the cut. The issues with the loyalty program could indicate that the company is struggling to retain customers, while weak consumer sentiment could suggest a decrease in demand for the company's products. Tariff headwinds could be increasing the company's costs, further impacting its financial performance. The store challenges were not specified but could range from operational issues to decreased foot traffic. Overall, this news is likely to negatively impact investor sentiment and could lead to further declines in the company's share price.

title: Sweetgreen’s customers are cutting back on pricey salads. Will extra chicken help?
description: Sweetgreen’s stock is sliding toward its worst day on record, and the company says it’s boosting some portion sizes to enhance the value proposition.
patterns: This situation is similar to Chipotle's in 2016, when they increased portion sizes to boost sales after a food safety scandal.
explanation: Sweetgreen's stock is experiencing a significant downturn, which suggests that investor confidence in the company is wavering. This downturn is largely due to customers cutting back on their expensive salads, a key product in Sweetgreen's offerings. In response, the company is increasing portion sizes, presumably to enhance the perceived value of their products and entice customers to continue buying. However, this strategy could potentially backfire. Increasing portion sizes could lead to increased costs for Sweetgreen, which could further impact their financial performance. Additionally, if the larger portion sizes don't attract enough additional sales, the company could be left with excess inventory, which would also negatively impact their bottom line. Given these potential risks, the news is bearish for Sweetgreen's stock and the Food & Beverage market overall.

Furthermore, it could also lead to a perception of decreased quality if customers associate larger portions with lower quality ingredients. This news is therefore likely to have a negative impact on the company's financial performance in the short term. However, the long-term effects will depend on the customers' response to the new portions and whether it can effectively drive sales.

title: European indices close mixed.German Dax, UK FTSE unchanged.  Spain, Italy, France higher.
description:
The European indices are closing mixed, with the German DAX and UK's FTSE 100 unchanged and France's CAC, Spain's Ibex, and Italy's FTSE MIB all higher. For the week, the major indices are all closing sharply higher.

A snapshot of the day shows

  • German Dax unchanged
  • France's CAC, +0.44%
  • UK's FTSE 100 -0.06%
  • Spain's Ibex, +0.91%
  • Italy's FTSE MIB, +0.56%

Looking at the weekly chart the major indices sans the UK FTSE 100 which did not like the BOE dovish cut rose smartly:

  • German DAX +3.28% which was it largest gain since April 28 week
  • France's CAC, +2.61% which was also its largest gain since April 28 week
  • UK's FTSE 100 +0.30%
  • Spain's Ibex, +4.94% which was it largest gain since April 14 week
  • Italy's FTSE MIB +4.21% which was its largest gain since April 14.

As London/European traders head for the exits, the US stock indices are also trading higher with a snapshot of the major indices currently showing:

  • Dow industrial average +127 points or 0.29% at 44093.61
  • S&P index up 37.73 points or 0.60% at 6377.84
  • NASDAQ index +164 points or 0.78% at 21407.36.
This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: The indices are showing a similar pattern to the week of April 28, where the DAX and CAC saw significant gains. The Ibex and FTSE MIB are also following a pattern similar to the week of April 14, where they also experienced large gains.
explanation: This article reports a mixed closing for the European indices, with the German DAX and UK's FTSE 100 remaining unchanged, while France's CAC, Spain's Ibex, and Italy's FTSE MIB all closed higher. Despite the mixed closing, the week saw all major indices closing sharply higher, with the German DAX and France's CAC experiencing their largest gains since the week of April 28. The Spanish Ibex and Italy's FTSE MIB also saw their largest gains since the week of April 14. This bullish trend in the European markets is likely to have a positive influence on investor sentiment and could lead to increased market activity. Additionally, the US stock indices are also trading higher, which suggests a positive outlook for global markets. The confidence level is high due to the clear bullish trend across multiple major indices.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond relaunches with first store in Nashville, plans dozens more
description: Bed Bath & Beyond has been resurrected after filing for bankruptcy in 2023 and liquidating. Its new owners are looking to open dozens of stores through 2026.
patterns: Similar to the rebirth of Toys 'R' Us after its bankruptcy in 2017.
explanation: The news of Bed Bath & Beyond's resurrection is a positive sign for the retail and consumer goods sectors. After filing for bankruptcy in 2023 and liquidating, the company's new owners are planning to open dozens of stores through 2026. This shows a strong confidence in the brand's ability to rebound and thrive, despite past financial struggles. The decision to open dozens of new stores indicates that the new owners see potential for growth and profitability in the brand. This could lead to job creation and increased consumer spending, both of which are positive for the economy. Furthermore, this move could be a sign of a broader recovery in the retail sector, which has been struggling in recent years due to the rise of e-commerce. Overall, this news is bullish for the retail and consumer goods markets.

title: We're buying the post-earnings dip in a restaurant stock controlling what it can
description: We're adding back half the 80 shares we sold around $190 in May, and upgrading our rating to 1.
markets: Restaurant Industry, Food and Beverage, Stocks
patterns: Similar to the post-earnings dip observed in Chipotle's stock in 2018, where the dip was followed by a significant rise.
explanation: The decision to buy back the post-earnings dip in a restaurant stock demonstrates a bullish sentiment towards the stock. This move suggests that the buyer perceives the dip as a temporary setback and anticipates a recovery or growth in the stock's value. The fact that the buyer is adding back half of the 80 shares sold around $190 in May indicates a renewed confidence in the stock's performance. Additionally, the upgrade of the rating to 1, typically the highest rating in investment analysis, signifies a strong positive outlook. This could potentially stimulate other investors to follow suit, thus driving up the demand and price of the stock. However, as with all investments, this move carries risk as the future performance of the stock is uncertain and dependent on various factors including the overall performance of the restaurant industry and the broader market trends.

title: Wall Street analysts rush to Eli Lilly's defense but investors aren't listening yet

Therefore, while this news is bearish, it is not significantly so.

title: Why a proposal to ‘save’ Social Security by investing $1.5 trillion in the stock market won’t work
description: Some in Congress have finally worked out that some of your Social Security retirement dollars should be invested. But is it too late?
patterns: Similar to the 2008 financial crisis, when government funds were invested in the stock market, resulting in a significant loss.
explanation: The proposal to invest $1.5 trillion of Social Security funds into the stock market is a risky move, which could potentially lead to significant losses. While the stock market has historically provided substantial returns, it's also characterized by volatility and unpredictability. If the market experiences a downturn, the retirement funds of millions of Americans could be at risk, which would have a negative impact on consumer spending and the economy as a whole. Furthermore, this move could also lead to an increase in stock prices due to the sudden influx of funds, creating a bubble that could burst and lead to a market crash. Therefore, while the intention to improve the financial health of the Social Security program is commendable, the method proposed is fraught with potential issues and risks.

title: Why a proposal to ‘save’ Social Security by investing $1.5 trillion in the stock market won’t work
description: Some in Congress have finally worked out that some of your Social Security retirement dollars should be invested. But is it too late?
patterns: Similar to the 1990s when the US government considered investing Social Security funds in the stock market, but ultimately did not proceed due to concerns about risks and political influence.
explanation: The proposal to invest $1.5 trillion of Social Security retirement dollars in the stock market is unlikely to work for several reasons. Firstly, the stock market is inherently volatile and unpredictable, making it a risky place to invest funds that are meant to provide a stable source of income for retirees. Secondly, such a large investment could potentially disrupt the balance of the market, causing instability and potentially leading to a bubble. Additionally, the government's involvement in the stock market could lead to conflicts of interest and political influence over market decisions. Furthermore, this proposal could potentially delay the necessary reforms needed to ensure the long-term solvency of the Social Security system. Instead of looking for quick fixes, policymakers should focus on sustainable solutions to the Social Security funding problem, such as increasing payroll taxes or raising the retirement age.

title: Is Apple making the same mistakes as Blackberry? Here’s how it can change course.
description: Apple seems to be lacking vision around AI, but one analyst recommends the company make a splashy acquisition and pay up for top AI hires.
patterns: This situation is reminiscent of Blackberry's downfall, where they failed to innovate and keep pace with the technological advancements of their competitors.
explanation: The article suggests that Apple is potentially making the same mistakes as Blackberry did, particularly in its lack of vision around artificial intelligence (AI). This could have negative implications for Apple's competitiveness in the tech market, especially given the increasing importance of AI in various aspects of technology. If Apple fails to prioritize AI, it risks falling behind its competitors who are investing heavily in this field. The recommendation for Apple to make a splashy acquisition and pay up for top AI hires suggests that the company needs to take drastic steps to catch up. However, such a move could also be risky and costly. It's worth noting that Apple's brand and customer loyalty are significantly stronger than Blackberry's were, which could mitigate some of the potential negative impact. Nevertheless, Apple's perceived lack of innovation in AI is a concern that could impact investor confidence and the company's future growth prospects.

title: Is Apple making the same mistakes as Blackberry? Here’s how it can change course.
description: Apple seems to be lacking vision around AI, but one analyst recommends the company make a splashy acquisition and pay up for top AI hires.
patterns: This situation is reminiscent of Blackberry's downfall in the smartphone market due to its inability to innovate and keep up with the competition.
explanation: The article suggests that Apple is potentially making the same mistakes as Blackberry did in the past by not focusing enough on innovation, particularly in the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI). This could have negative implications for Apple's future growth and profitability, hence the negative impact score. However, the analyst's recommendation for Apple to make a significant acquisition and invest in top AI talent could potentially reverse this course, hence the medium confidence level. The tech market, AI sector, and NASDAQ (where Apple's shares are traded) could be affected by these developments. It's important for Apple to heed these warnings in order to avoid the fate of Blackberry, which lost significant market share due to its lack of innovation and inability to keep up with technological advancements.

title: Are you getting a $600 tariff rebate check? What to know as Trump, senator float the idea.
patterns: Similar events include the tax rebates issued by the George W. Bush administration in 2001 and 2008 to stimulate the economy.
explanation: The idea of a $600 tariff rebate check being floated by President Trump and a senator could have a positive impact on the economy, hence a score of 1. This could increase consumer spending, particularly in the retail sector, as people have more disposable income. However, the confidence level is only medium as it is still just an idea and not a confirmed policy. Moreover, the impact of such rebates on the economy can be varied. In similar situations in the past, such as the tax rebates issued by the George W. Bush administration in 2001 and 2008, the impact on the economy was positive but short-lived. Therefore, while this news could boost consumer spending and the retail sector in the short term, it may not have a long-term positive effect on the US economy.

title: Are you getting a $600 tariff rebate check? What to know as Trump, senator float the idea.
patterns: This proposal is similar to the tax rebate checks distributed under the George W. Bush administration in 2008, which were intended to stimulate the economy during the financial crisis.
explanation: The idea of a $600 tariff rebate check being floated by President Trump and a senator would likely have a positive impact on consumer spending, hence the bullish impact rating. If consumers receive an extra $600, they are likely to spend a portion of it, particularly in the retail and consumer goods sectors. This could provide a boost to these sectors, particularly if the checks are distributed at a time when consumer confidence is otherwise low. However, the confidence in this analysis is only medium, as it is not yet clear whether this proposal will be implemented. Furthermore, the overall impact on the economy may be limited if the checks are funded by increased tariffs, which could have a negative impact on other sectors of the economy, particularly those involved in international trade.

title: Are you getting a $600 tariff rebate check? What to know as Trump, senator float the idea.
patterns: Historically, government stimulus checks have led to increased consumer spending.
explanation: The news of a possible $600 tariff rebate check being floated by President Trump and a senator can potentially have a positive impact on the economy, hence the bullish rating of 2. If implemented, this rebate check could increase consumer spending, particularly in the retail and consumer goods sectors. However, the confidence level is medium due to the uncertainty surrounding the proposal. It's not clear whether it will pass, when it would be implemented, or who would be eligible to receive it. Historically, government stimulus checks have led to increased consumer spending, which can stimulate economic growth. However, this is dependent on the scale of the distribution and the financial circumstances of the recipients. Therefore, while the proposal could have a positive impact, the uncertainty surrounding it tempers the potential bullish impact.

title: Trump and Putin summit is tentatively scheduled for the end of next week
description:
A Trump-Putin summit is tentatively scheduled for the end of next week.

In a sign of solidarity and compromise, Ukraine's president Zelenskiy is saying:

  • We all should support US constructive effort to reach a cease-fire in Ukraine

Hopefully, there is as much compromise in the forthcoming negotiations to end the war from both sides.

US stocks are extending higher. The Nasdaq is up near 200 points or 0.92% (it is up 195 points now).

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Historically, summits between US and Russia have led to temporary market optimism due to potential diplomatic resolution.
explanation: The news of the tentatively scheduled summit between President Trump and President Putin has a mildly bullish impact on the US stock market. This is reflected in the Nasdaq's rise of nearly 200 points or 0.92%. Markets typically respond positively to signs of potential diplomatic resolutions, as they reduce geopolitical risks. This is especially true in the case of the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, where the US has significant interests. Additionally, President Zelenskiy of Ukraine's statement of support for US efforts to reach a ceasefire indicates a positive diplomatic environment, which further fuels market optimism. However, it's important to note that these effects are often temporary and can reverse if the summit does not yield tangible results. Sectors like defense and energy, which are directly impacted by US-Russia relations, may also see significant movement.

title: White House to clarify misinformation on gold tariffs
description:
From Bloomberg:

  • The Trump administration suggested it would issue a new policy clarifying that imports of gold bars should not face tariffs, after the government stunned traders by ruling that they would be subject to duties.

Comex gold futures surged to a new all-time high earlier in the day, but has since come off. The recent news sent the price down to test the rising 100-hour MA at $3446.10, but buyers have against the level and pushed the price back higher price and string $3464.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: EURUSD technicals:The EURUSD is consolidating near the week's highs buy above 50% midpoint
description:
The EURUSD began its upside move last Friday after finding support at the 100-day moving average, which served as a strong base for buyers. That momentum extended into this week, with the pair breaking above the 200-hour moving average and the 38.2% retracement (1.1558) of the decline from the July high. The bullish move continued past the 50% midpoint at 1.16098, confirming increased control by buyers.

On Thursday, the pair peaked just shy of 1.1700, a natural resistance level, before pulling back to retest the 50% retracement. Buyers held that line, reinforcing the bullish bias. While Friday’s high fell short of Thursday’s peak, the higher low kept buyers in the game and set the stage for a key test early next week.

From a technical standpoint:

  • A break below the 100-hour moving average (1.16156) and the 50% retracement (1.16098) would be needed to shift the bias back toward the downside and disappoint bulls.

  • Conversely, holding above those levels and pushing through the 61.8% retracement at 1.16815 would open the door for a retest of 1.1700, followed by the July highs at 1.1787 and 1.18289 as bullish target.

The video above outlines the key levels and explains all the "whys" for the key levels.

Visit investingLive.com daily and often.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: China July data - China’s consumer price inflation flat y/y, but higher than expected m/m
description:
China’s consumer prices were flat y/y in July, as government efforts to rein in excessive competition offered some relief from deflationary pressures. Analysts caution that the path out of deflation will be long and may require stronger stimulus measures.

Consumer Price Index (YoY) (July) 0.0%,

  • no change from a year earlier, beating forecasts for a small decline
  • a second month without negative readings
  • expected -0.1%, prior +0.1%

Consumer Price Index (MoM) (July) +0.4%

  • expected +0.3%, prior -0.1%

Producer Price Index (YoY) (July) -3.6%

  • factory-gate prices continued to fall
  • producer price index down for the 34th consecutive month of producer deflation
  • expected -3.3%, prior -3.6%

Authorities have launched a campaign to curb price wars (Chinese policy shift to “Anti-involution”) that have been squeezing company profits and wages, but analysts warn that deeper problems remain. Household expectations for future prices have weakened, and the GDP deflator — a broad gauge of economy-wide prices — has now fallen for nine straight quarters, the longest decline in decades.

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.

title: Iran bans nuclear site visits ahead of IAEA talks after strikes, demands new terms
description:
Iran says no visits to its nuclear facilities are planned as it meets with the U.N. atomic watchdog on Monday, according to Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi.

  • “Negotiations with the IAEA will be held tomorrow to determine a framework for cooperation,” he said on his Telegram account,
  • adding, “A Deputy Director General of Grossi will come to Tehran tomorrow, while there are no plans to visit any nuclear sites until we reach a framework.”

Since Israel’s strikes on Iran’s nuclear sites during a 12-day conflict in June, inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) have been barred from accessing facilities — despite IAEA chief Rafael Grossi naming inspections as his top priority. Tehran accuses the agency of laying the groundwork for the bombings through a critical May 31 report, which prompted the IAEA’s 35-nation board to rule Iran in breach of its non-proliferation commitments.

Iran, which denies seeking nuclear weapons, says it remains committed to the Non-Proliferation Treaty. However, a law passed last month suspends cooperation with the IAEA, requiring any future inspections to be approved by the Supreme National Security Council.

---

This is weekend news. Oil futures will open for trade in about 90 minutes, at 1800 US Eastern time Sunday (2200 GMT)

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.

title: Michigan Governor Whitmer tells Trump tariffs are hurting Michigan autos
description:
Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer met privately with President Donald Trump in the Oval Office on Tuesday to deliver a message: his tariffs were damaging the very automotive industry he has pledged to protect. The conversation marked Whitmer’s third meeting with Trump at the White House since he took office in January.

AP carried the report. In brief:

In the closed-door discussion, Whitmer warned that the economic fallout from the tariffs could be severe for Michigan, a state whose support was pivotal in Trump’s 2024 election victory. She also pressed for federal aid to support recovery efforts after a recent ice storm and urged the administration to delay planned changes to Medicaid that could affect residents’ healthcare coverage.

According to people familiar with the meeting, Trump offered no specific commitments in response. Those sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity to describe the private exchange, said the president listened but gave no indication he would reconsider his trade policy.

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.

title: Another Chinese property developer bites the dust - China South City ordered to liquidate
description:
The Hong Kong High Court has ordered the liquidation of South City, making it the largest Chinese property developer by assets to be wound up since China Evergrande Group.

The company failed to secure sufficient creditor backing for its restructuring plan after months of negotiations, underscoring how China’s prolonged property downturn continues to topple once-dominant real estate firms.

Share trading of the firm has been halted.

The moribund property sector, mired in debt, continues to drag on the Chinese economy

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.

title: investingLive Asia-Pacific FX news wrap: Nvidia, AMD 15% China chip sale revenues to US
description:
Fed Governor Bowman called for rate cuts at all remaining 2025 meetings, citing labour market weakness over inflation risks. China’s July CPI and PPI were released, while FT reported Nvidia and AMD will give 15% of China chip sales revenue to the US for export licences — news that failed to dent tech sentiment. Markets were quiet with Japan on holiday, the USD a touch softer, and FX in tight ranges.

  • Trump says hopes China will quickly x4 it orders for soybeans (quadruple)
  • New Zealand Prime Minister Luxon says US tariff relief is unlikely
  • BTC/USD is back above US$121K
  • Ether on the move: ETH/USD to its highest since December 2021
  • Deutsche Bank sees July US CPI slowing to 0.1% as markets watch core inflation trend
  • Michigan Governor Whitmer tells Trump tariffs are hurting Michigan autos
  • PBOC sets USD/ CNY reference rate for today at 7.1405 (vs. estimate at 7.1845)
  • China seeking to cut lithium production - fears of oversupply
  • China July PPI falls 3.6%, CPI flat: Weak demand, housing slump keep deflation fears alive
  • Reserve Bank of Australia expected to cut its cash rate this week by 25bp
  • Report that Nvidia, AMD to pay 15% export tax to US govmnt getting more widely reported
  • ICYMI - On Saturday Fed Governor Bowman called for 3 FOMC rate cuts this year
  • ES and NQ (and others!) are open on Globex, both are up
  • US equity index futures are about to open - to HUGE news ... not in a good way
  • Japan is on Mountain Day holiday today - markets are closed. US bond trade impacted.
  • Reports that Nvidia and AMD to pay 15% of China chip sale revenues to US government
  • FT reports on Putin Trump meeting, Putin "has no intention of winding down the war"
  • Iran bans nuclear site visits ahead of IAEA talks after strikes, demands new terms
  • US eyes October deadline to seal trade deals. Canada, Mexico, Switzerland seek terms.
  • Monday open levels, indicative FX prices, 11 August 2025
  • Newsquawk Week Ahead: US CPI, US Retail Sales, China CPI, RBA, Aussie & UK Jobs
  • China July data - China’s consumer price inflation flat y/y, but higher than expected m/m
  • Fed Board Governor Bowman calls for September rate cut, and another two by year end

We had a few market-relevant developments over the weekend. US Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman, who dissented from the FOMC’s July decision to hold rates steady, said in a Saturday speech that she favours rate cuts at each of the remaining 2025 meetings — in September, October, and December. She argued that weakness in the US labour market outweighs the risk of renewed inflation.

From China, July CPI and PPI data were released (details in earlier posts). The biggest headline of the day came in early Asia hours, with the Financial Times reporting that Nvidia and AMD have agreed to hand over 15% of their China chip sales revenue to the US government in exchange for export licences. While this might have been expected to weigh on the stocks and NASDAQ futures, both saw modest gains after the news.

Elsewhere, news flow was extremely light. In the US, a defence official said the military is preparing for a possible order from President Trump to activate part of the D.C. National Guard for deployment in Washington. Japanese markets were closed for a holiday, dampening liquidity. The US dollar was slightly softer, with major FX pairs trading in narrow ranges.

Asia-Pac stocks:

Australia (S&P/ASX 200) +0.28%

Hong Kong (Hang Seng) +0.26%

Japan (Nikkei 225) ... closed for a holiday

Shanghai Composite +0.5%

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.

title: US inflation data to set the tone for markets this week
description:
The US CPI report is the be all and end all for markets in trading this week. After the recent string of poor data, traders have gone on to price in a September rate cut as Fed policymakers also start to turn more dovishly. But what happens if inflation runs hotter than expected?

Stagflation risks are on the rise and this is now becoming the key buzzword that markets are turning to.

Looking at the numbers, headline inflation in July is expected to see a monthly increase of 0.2% (lower than 0.3% in June). However, the annual figure is still estimated to rise to 2.8% (up from 2.7% previously).

As for core inflation, the monthly figure is expected to increase by 0.3% (up from 0.2% in June) with the year-on-year estimate seen at 3.0% (up from 2.9% previously).

The core figures are obviously the more important element but the devil will still be in the details with the report. The key thing will be to watch out for any further tariffs passthrough from businesses to consumers. If there is more evidence of that, it will be a bit of an issue for the Fed.

But at this stage, I can see them pulling out a leaf out of the old playbook. The whole "inflation is transitory" framing a few years ago comes to mind and I imagine policymakers using that again to sell rate cuts towards the end of this year. The thinking would be that tariffs inflation would just bump up prices temporarily.

So, we'll have to look forward to. But whatever the case is, stickier inflation numbers will just make the Fed's job a whole lot tougher. And it will also keep markets on their toes before September.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.

title: What are the main events for today?
description:
It's going to be kind of a synthetic Sunday today as we don't have anything on the agenda. The main event of the week is the US CPI report tomorrow, so we might see the market either consolidating ahead of the release or keep following the trend set by the dovish Fedspeak.

Over the weekend, we had Fed's Bowman supporting three rate cuts by year-end and she even added that more weakness in the labour market could call for a bigger rate cut. The recent Fedspeak suggests that a rate cut in September might be unavoidable, we might need very hot inflation data to change their mind (and of course a good NFP report in September).

They don't have the guts to look through some labour market weakness at this point. Therefore, the CPI tomorrow might need to come in higher than expected to change the market pricing and then it will be a matter of focusing on Fedspeak and Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole Symposium to see whether they are still on board for a cut in September.

This article was written by Giuseppe Dellamotta at investinglive.com.

title: Taiwan says that tariff negotiations with US are still ongoing
description:
As a reminder, Taiwan was slapped with 20% tariffs in the latest twist to the tariffs saga. But they are reaffirming that negotiations are still ongoing, with the goal being to "seek a better and more reasonable tariff rate".

It's the same case for many countries, even those that have reportedly struck a "deal" with the US before the 1 August deadline. These deals seem to be framework agreements at best as is the case for the EU, UK, Japan, and also China to some degree. They are mainly just a pact to deal temporarily with lower tariffs while supposedly trying to negotiate for better terms.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.

title: Gold eases to start the week, traders await US tariffs clarification
description:
Gold futures, more specifically COMEX contracts, surged at the end of last week as the US customs agency is said to have marked the precious metal as being subject to tariffs. The spot market was much calmer as noted here, as traders were also waiting for the White House to make a mention about it.

But as we get into the new week, there's still no clarity on the matter. So, it's still a bit of a limbo situation. When it comes to tariffs, Trump has the final say. And if we don't hear anything, it's hard to take other sources as confirmation really.

For now, traders are still assessing the situation. But even if the tariffs are confirmed, it really comes down to what the intention from the US really is as mentioned in the linked post.

Going back to gold prices today, we are seeing COMEX futures fall back from the surge higher on Friday. The spread between COMEX futures and LME futures have narrowed back to around $60, roughly similar to back before the jump. For some context, the spike higher on Friday saw the spread hit over $120 at the peak.

And as the situation cools, so are gold prices at the spot level.

The near-term chart shows buyers have lost the more bullish bias, with price action dipping back below the 100-hour moving average (red line). The 1% drop today now puts the focus back on the 200-hour moving average (blue line) at around $3,352 currently. Hold that line and the near-term bias stays more neutral with buyers keeping some relevance. But break below that, and the near-term bias switches back to being more bearish in favouring sellers.

While we continue to wait on the White House to say something, if they ever do, the big picture still shows gold largely consolidating since May. And we're yet to really break that stride over the last few months. So, the next significant move will come on a break of this consolidative phase for the most part.

To the upside, gold will have to first contest the May, June, and July highs around $3,435-50 before thinking about another shot at the $3,500 mark. As for the downside, the 100-day moving average (red line) at $3,292 currently is a big, big one to watch. Gold has not firmly broken that mark since October 2023. So, if we do get a notable correction, that might be the key trigger for one.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.

title: Technical Analysis: What technical levels are driving the EURUSD, USDJPY & GBPUSD
description:
The USD is at the highs to start the day vs most of the major currencies, but still relatively little changed. In the video above, I take a technical look at the EURUSD, USDJPY and GBPUSD and outline the bias, the targets and the risks for each.

This week, the key events begin early Tuesday in the US with the Reserve Bank of Australia’s policy decision at 12:30 A.M. ET (Aug 12), where the cash rate is expected to decline to 3.60% from 3.85%. This will be accompanied by the RBA’s Monetary Policy Statement, rate statement, and press conference. Australia’s data flow continues later in the week with the Wage Price Index on Tue, Aug 12 at 9:30 P.m. ET, forecast to rise 0.8% q/q, followed by labor market figures on Wed, Aug 13 at 9:30 p.m. ET, with employment change expected at 25.3K (vs 2.0K last month) and the unemployment rate declining to 4.2% from 4.3%.

In the U.S., the focus this week is on inflation, spending, and sentiment. July CPI is released Tue, Aug 12 at 8:30 a.m. ET, with headline CPI forecast at +0.2% m/m (core +0.3%) and the y/y rate rising to 2.8%(from 2.7%). Producer prices follow on Thu, Aug 14 at 8:30 a.m. ET, with headline PPI expected to rise by 0.2% and core PPI also up 0.2%. At the same time, weekly jobless claims are projected at 225K (vs 226K last week). Retail sales are out Fri, Aug 15 at 8:30 a.m. ET, with headline sales seen up 0.5% m/m (vs 0.6% last) and core +0.3% (vs 0.5%). The week wraps with the University of Michigan’s preliminary consumer sentiment on Fri at 10:00 a.m. ET, expected at 61.9, with inflation expectations at 4.5%.

From the U.K., the key release is GDP m/m on Thu, Aug 14 at 2:00 a.m. ET, forecast to rebound 0.2% in July after a 0.1% decline in June, offering an early read on third-quarter growth momentum.

Over the weekend, Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman, who holds a permanent vote on the FOMC and a dove, signaled support for three rate cuts by the end of 2025, citing a sharp deterioration in the U.S. labor market. Speaking at a bankers’ conference in Colorado Springs, she pointed to significant downward revisions in recent nonfarm payrolls — May revised from 144,000 to 19,000 (-125,000) and June from 147,000 to 14,000 (-133,000) — as evidence of weakening economic momentum. Bowman argued that the apparent slowdown in growth and a less dynamic labor market outweigh the risks of higher inflation, making it appropriate to move from a moderately restrictive stance toward neutral. She expects to back a cut at each of the Fed’s remaining meetings this year — September 16–17, October 28–29, and December 9–10 — aligning with recent dovish signals from other Fed officials including Daly, Waller, Williams, and Kashkari.

Also over the weekend , Nvidia and AMD have reached an unprecedented agreement with the Trump administration to give the U.S. government 15% of revenues from certain chip sales in China in exchange for export licences. Under the deal, Nvidia will share 15% of revenue from H20 chip sales, while AMD will provide the same percentage from MI308 chip sales to China. The arrangement, confirmed by a U.S. official, was a condition for licences granted last week, shortly after Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang met with President Trump. The administration has not yet determined how the funds will be used. Export control experts note that no U.S. company has previously agreed to share revenues to secure export approval, marking this as a first-of-its-kind arrangement aligned with the administration’s broader strategy of tying market access to measures that generate U.S. jobs and revenue. Wow. Who would have thought the US goverment would have a revenue sharing deal with US companies? Has a dam just been broken?

Later this week Trump and Putin will meet in Alaska to try and end the war in Ukraine. The proposal for Ukraine to cede land to Russia is a contentious point of discussion. Ukraine President Zelenskiy said over the weekend that Ukraine could not violate its constitution on the territorial issues, adding that "Ukrainians will not gift their land to the occupiers."

Shares of the two companies are down in premarket trading. Nvidia shares are trained down $1.01 or 0.55% at $181.67. Meanwhile AMD shares are down $2.90 or -1.68% at $169.86.

  • Dow industrial average is up 126 point
  • S&P index is up 13.55 points
  • NASDAQ index is up 38 points

in the US debt market yields are down modestly with the longer end lower:

  • 2-year yield 3.760%, +0.2 basis points
  • 5-year yield 3.820%, -0.7 basis points
  • 10 year yield 4.269%, -1.4 basis points
  • 30 year yield 4.831%, -2.3 basis points
This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: EURUSD technicals: EURUSD falls to the next key support target
description:
EURUSD has pushed to fresh session lows, pressing against a key technical pivot — the 50% retracement of the drop from the July 1 high at 1.16098. Earlier in the U.S. session, the pair slipped under its 100-hour moving average at 1.16312 (blue line), flipping the near-term bias to the downside. For sellers, that MA now serves as close risk, and staying below it keeps the bearish tone intact.

A decisive break under 1.16098 would clear the way for a run toward the 200-hour MA at 1.15648. Until then, this midpoint is the battleground. In recent sessions, EURUSD has been capped between that 1.16098 level and Wednesday’s high at 1.1698, making today’s test all the more significant. Sellers have the upper hand — now it’s about whether they can punch through and extend the momentum.

I spoke to these levels in the video from earlier today.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: USDCAD technicals: USDCAD moved above the 100 day MA. It did not go well.
description:
USDCAD pushed higher in today’s session, breaking above the 200-hour MA at 1.37817 and the 100-day MA at 1.37876. From a technical perspective, those breaks should have been meaningful and set the stage for additional upside momentum. Instead, the rally quickly lost steam, and the price slipped back below both levels, leaving traders to question whether the move was simply overextended.

For USD sellers, CAD buyers, or risk-focused traders, the 100-day MA now serves as a clear level to lean against for short setups. A sustained move lower from here opens the door to the 38.2% retracement at 1.37626, with the 100-hour MA at 1.3754 providing the next downside target.

If price moves below both those levels, focus shifts to the 50% retracement, which would be the next logical support zone.

Recall that last week — the pair broke below the 50% retracement, but the momentum failed, and USDCAD based out before reversing higher.

Traders should be mindful of a similar outcome here. Failed breaks are something traders should be wary about technically. Nevertheless, if the buyers return and push above the 100 day MA, I would not mess with the short side (it represents the risk and bias defining level)

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: Trump tariff revenues reached $29.6B in July. Has it peaked?
description:
The Trump tariff revenues reached $29.6B in July which was a billion or two more than the $28B collected in June. Tariff revenues rose steadily from $17.4 billion in April to $23.9 billion in May, before climbing to $28 billion in June.

At $29.6B running rate (call it $30B per month), that would reach $360B for the year. That is more collected than ever, but it is not the $700B that Commerce Sec. Lutnick touted on Sunday news shows back at the end of July.

See: https://investinglive.com/news/lutnick-no-more-extensions-of-tariffs-past-august-1-700b-in-tariffs-will-be-collected-20250727/

Pinochio?

Goldman over the weekend, estimated that:

  • 64% is being paid by US companies
  • 22% by US consumers
  • 14% by others(? - maybe by foreign company lowering their prices)

Can that mix continue keeping inflation lower?

It can, and if other inflation moves lower, the door could open for the Fed to cut rates going forward. Fed's Bowman sees three cuts between now and the end of the year.

For companies to eat the 64%, they will need to find it somewhere. Increasing efficiency, cutting payroll are some ways. For the consumer, it cost more for imported goods, but will services prices go down and soften the blow? Of course it does not impact all goods. According to a Federal Reserve analysis, imports account for about 11% of total U.S. consumer spending, and this figure has been stable for over a decade.

BTW... My wife and I wanted something for lunch on Saturday while we did some errands. So I suggested McDonalds as time was limited (we do not go there often). For a two cheeseburger meal (which we split) it came to $12.30. Wow.

The average tariff rate moved down after August 1 suggesting the US may have we peaked in tariff revenue?

Anyway, getting to $700B might be difficult. We will see..

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: Trump: We'll see what happens with the China deadline. Putin meeting is a feel out meeting
description:
Trump on China:

  • On the deadline (expiring on August 12), we'll see what happens with the deadline
  • They (China) have been dealing nicely.
  • Says he has a very good relationship with Chinese Pres. Xi.

So far there has been no formal announcement about whether he will endorse an extension or push ahead with the higher tariffs.

On meeting with Putin:

  • It is a feeling out meeting
  • I'm going to tell him to end the war.
  • Think will have constructive conversation.
  • Next meeting will be with Zelenskiy, or with Putin and Zelenskiy.
  • There will be some swapping, changes in land.
  • Will see the parameters, may leave and say good luck.
  • Will also call European leaders after meeting
  • I would like to see a cease-fire.
  • Says that Zelenskiy can go to the meeting.(that is something new)
  • He can see increased trade with Russia following a Ukraine deal.
  • Think it will be good but it migh be bad.
  • Ultimately I will put Zelenskiy and Putin in a room, and I think there will be a deal.

On Nvidia:

  • Nvidia is selling an old chip that essentially Huawai has.
  • I released them from the H20
  • On the Blackwell, will be an unenhanced version of that chip
  • There may be another meeting.
This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: Major European indices closed the day with mixed results
description:
The major European indices closed the day with mixed results. The decliners were the German DAX, France's CAC, and Italy's FTSE MIB. The UK FTSE 100 and Spain's Ibex moved higher.

A summary of the closing levels shows:

  • German DAX, -0.34%
  • France's CAC, -0.57%
  • Italy's FTSE MIB -0.10%

The winners:

  • UKs FTSE 100 +0.37%
  • Spain's Ibex +0.21%

US major indices are also mixed with the Dow industrial average down modestly, but the broader S&P and NASDAQ indices are higher.

  • Dow industrial average -20 points or -0.05% at 44154
  • S&P +14.15 points or 0.22% at 6403.56
  • NASDAQ index up 84 points or 0.39% at 21534.
  • Russell 2000 is up 4.93 points or 0.22% at 2223.45.

Nvidia and AMD shares were lower at the start of the day after agreed to pay 15% month export of their chips to China. Both have recovered and are trading in positive territory:

  • Nvidia is trading up $1.09 or 0.58% at $183.77
  • AMD is trading up three dollars or 1.77% at $175.84.

Other chip stocks are higher with:

  • Broadcom up $2.47 or 0.81% at $307.44
  • Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan is expected to visit the White House. Last week, President Donald Trump’s called for his immediate resignation over his alleged ties to China. Share of Intel are trading up $1.16 or 5.81% at $21.11.
This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: AUDUSD technicals: AUDUSD consolidates around MA levels
description:
The AUDUSD is trading near its session lows, but the day’s range is only 34 pips — a sign of restrained price action ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia’s rate decision in the new trading day. The RBA is widely expected to cut rates by 25 bps to 3.60% at 12:30 AM ET, following a February cut from 4.35% to 4.10% and a second cut in May to 3.85%. Last month, the central bank surprised by holding rates steady, signaling that timing rather than direction was the priority.

Market expectations are firmly in place for this move — a Reuters poll showed unanimous agreement for a cut, with most economists also expecting one more reduction before year-end. Softer inflation and labor market data are helping pave the way. CPI has eased toward the lower bound of the RBA’s 2–3% target, with Q2 headline inflation falling to 2.1% y/y, its lowest since March 2021 and below the 2.2% forecast. June jobs growth added just 2,000 jobs versus expectations of around 20,000, marking the weakest gain since October 2024, while unemployment ticked up to 4.3% from 4.1%.

Technically, the pair is holding just under its 200-bar MA (0.6528) and 100-bar MA (0.6513) on the 4-hour chart. These averages sit above the midpoint of the broad range in place since April 23, which spans from the low at 0.63546 to the high at 0.6625 (midpoint 0.6489). Today’s low of 0.6502 leaves price roughly 13 pips above that midpoint. Staying below the 100-bar MA favors sellers, while a move back above the 200-bar MA would hand the advantage to buyers.

On the downside, a break below the 0.6489 midpoint would expose a swing area near 0.64519, the 100-day MA at 0.64375, and the 200-day MA at 0.6389. Given weaker domestic data and the anticipated rate cut, the fundamental backdrop leans bearish for AUDUSD — but with U.S. rate expectations also shifting lower, the impact may be muted. In this type of sideways, range-bound environment, using the moving averages as bias-defining barometers may be the cleaner play for traders.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: Crude oil settles at $63.96
description:
The price of crude oil futures are settling eight cents higher at $63.96. The high price today reached $64.44 the low price was at $63.02.

Looking at the hourly chart, the price consolidation seen over the last few days has led to the 100-hour moving average catching up with the price. The current 100 hour moving average is at $64.49 and moving lower. Going forward, a move above that moving average would be the first since August 1, and would tilt the bias in the short term to the upside.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: investingLive Americas FX news wrap 11 Aug:Modest changes in the markets ahead of CPI data
description:
• US stocks close lower. Nasdaq trades to a new intraday high before rotating lower
  • Crude oil settles at $63.96
  • Trump extends China tariff deadlines 90 days
  • Add FOMCs Bowman, Jefferson and Dallas Fed Pres. Logan to list of Fed Chair
  • Trump: Gold will not be tariffed
  • Major European indices closed the day with mixed results
  • Trump: We'll see what happens with the China deadline. Putin meeting is a feel out meeting
  • After sending in National Guard to LA, Trump now sends them to Washington DC
  • Trump tariff revenues reached $29.6B in July. Has it peaked?
  • NVDA stock analysis today with orderFlow Intel @ investingLive
  • Technical Analysis: What technical levels are driving the EURUSD, USDJPY & GBPUSD
  • investingLive European markets wrap: Dollar steady, gold slips; markets wait on US CPI

The US dollar is settling higher versus the major currency pairs. The biggest gain was versus the NZD (0.34%). The greenback rose by 0.18% versus the AUD ahead of its interest rate decision in the new trading day. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut rates by 25 basis points in reaction to lower inflation (2.1% year) and some weaker jobs data.

Tomorrow the US CPI will be released at 8:30 AM ET with the month-to-month expected to rise by 0.2% and the core up 0.3%. For the YoY, the headline is expected at 2.8% vs 2.7% last month. The Core is expected to tick up to 3.0% from 2.9% last month.

Focus will be on the goods inflation to see if the impact from tariffs is accelerating the inflationary pressures (or not).

Last month core goods narrowly pushed prices up by 0.2% m/m in June—a repeat of May’s increase

Core services inflation picked up to 0.3% m/m in June, up from around 0.2% the previous month.

  • Within that, shelter costs rose by 0.2%, marking the smallest monthly gain since August 2021.

The key takeaway from last month was goods price growth remains modest, suggesting limited inflation pressure from trade-sensitive sectors so far.

Services inflation, led by shelter, continues to provide underlying pressure in core CPI—highlighting its stickier contribution to overall inflation. However, the decline in shelter is a postive. Shelter accounts for 34% of the overall CPI weight - by far the greatest influence in the figure.

If goods inflation can remains elatively tame, it will give the dovish Fed officials more leeway to call for rate cut rates with the understanding that the tariff effect continues to remain subdued and the focus should shift to the risk from weaker employment (after the poor US jobs report at the beginning of the month).

The calendar was void of any data today. From Washington, Trump announced that China would get another reprieve from increased tariffs for 90 days.

Trump spoke of progress being made on peace negotitions between Ukraine and Russia as he prepares to meet with Russia's Putin later in the week. Trump described the meeting as a "feel out" meeting that he hopes to lead to the Putin and Zelenskiy getting together and calling a truce to the war

US stocks closed modestly lower, giving up earlier gains.

  • Dow -0.45%
  • S&P -0.25%
  • Nasdaq -0.50%

US yields are ending the session little changed with the 2-year up 0.08 basis points and the 20 year down -0.02%.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: Trump taps EJ Antoni to head BLS, sparking concerns over partisanship and expertise
description:
Trump taps EJ Antoni to head BLS, sparking concerns over partisanship and expertise

President Trump has nominated EJ Antoni, chief economist at the Heritage Foundation, to lead the Bureau of Labor Statistics, following Trump's dismissal of the previous commissioner over job report revisions.

The pick has drawn sharp criticism, much of it centred on Antoni’s reputation as a hyper-partisan figure.

While some of that pushback comes from across the political aisle, not all of it does. A more substantive concern is that Antoni is an economist rather than a statistician, raising questions over whether he has the technical background to run an agency whose work hinges on statistical rigour.

For markets, the key worry is the potential impact on the perceived reliability and integrity of the BLS’s data — including closely watched employment and inflation figures.

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.
