title: More Trump News: Thought Canada removing retaliatory tariffs was wise.
description:
President Trump remarked that Canada’s removal of retaliatory tariffs was “nice” and said he expects to have another call with Prime Minister Carney soon, emphasizing that he wants to be “good to Canada” and had a productive conversation yesterday.

Turning to Russia, Trump noted that President Vladimir Putin “may be coming” to the World Cup and expressed displeasure over the recent strike on a Russian pipeline. He reiterated that in the next two weeks “we’ll find out which way Russia and Ukraine will go.”

The comments highlight a striking contrast: Trump expressed enthusiasm about the prospect of hosting Putin at a sporting event on U.S. soil, an appearance that would require significant American security resources and create major public disruptions, while at the same time describing Putin—widely viewed as a war criminal—with a tone of welcome.

At the policy level, Trump signaled that economic sanctions on Russian oil remain part of his strategy to squeeze Moscow toward peace, yet criticized an attack on a pipeline that, while disruptive, is repairable. Meanwhile, Russia continues to escalate military action.

What a disaster, a pipeline was destroyed while military action is continuing to kill innnocent people.

What is wrong with the world.

On Powell:

  • Powell is still too late. He should have cut a year ago.

He did actually. He cut by 50BP in September ahead of the election and again in November and December.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: WTI crude oil futures settled at $63.66
description:
The price of crude oil is settling at $63.66, up $0.14 or 0.22%.

The high for the day reached $63.93, while the low came in at $63.31, leaving a relatively narrow trading range.

Looking across the week, the market established a low at $61.45 on Monday, before testing the falling 100-hour moving average and quickly rotating back down to a Tuesday low of $61.67.

From that point, momentum shifted as the price climbed above both the 100- and 200-hour moving averages, only to retrace back to the 100-hour average on Thursday, where buyers reemerged to defend support. The rebound carried through into today’s session, with the rally extending to $63.93 — the highest level of the week.

For the trading week, the price is up 1.05%. Although the price is above the 100/200-hour MA giving the buyers some control in the short term, the price is still below the 100-day MA at $64.36. The price is also below the 38.2% of the move down from the end of July high at $64.91. Getting and staying above both those levels is needed to give the buyers more control.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: Fitch affirms the US a AA+ with the outlook stable.
description:
U.S. Credit Ratings Overview

  • Fitch Ratings: The U.S. is rated AA+ with a Stable outlook, reflecting continued confidence in the country’s fiscal resilience.

  • S&P Global Ratings: The U.S. is rated AA+ with a Stable outlook, supported by tariff revenues and strong credit fundamentals.

  • Moody’s Investors Service: In May 2025, Moody’s downgraded the U.S. from Aaa to Aa1, citing concerns over debt and fiscal policy. The outlook is Stable.

As a point of comparison:

Canada

  • Fitch: AA+ (Stable)

  • S&P: AAA (Stable)

  • Moody’s: Aaa (Stable)

United Kingdom

  • Fitch: AA- (Stable)

  • S&P: AA (Stable)

  • Moody’s: Aa3 (Stable)

Eurozone (selected)

  • Germany: AAA across all three agencies (Stable)

  • France: Fitch AA-, S&P AA, Moody’s Aa2 (all Stable)

  • Italy: Fitch BBB, S&P BBB, Moody’s Baa3 (Stable)

  • Spain: Fitch A-, S&P A, Moody’s Baa1 (Stable)

Japan

  • Fitch: A (Stable)

  • S&P: A+ (Stable)

  • Moody’s: A1 (Stable)

China

  • Fitch: A+ (Stable)

  • S&P: A+ (Stable)

  • Moody’s: A1 (Stable)

Australia

  • Fitch: AAA (Stable)

  • S&P: AAA (Stable)

  • Moody’s: Aaa (Stable)

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: investingLive Americas FX news wrap 22 Aug: Markets cheer on Powell tilt (for now)
description:
• US major indices cheer on the Powell speech
  • Fitch affirms the US a AA+ with the outlook stable.
  • Russia's Putin: There is a light in the end of the tunnel in Russia-US relations
  • WTI crude oil futures settled at $63.66
  • More Trump News: Thought Canada removing retaliatory tariffs was wise.
  • Baker Hughes oil rig count -1 at 411
  • FHFA Director Pulte: I will be referring 2 more people this afternoon for mortgage fraud
  • Major European indices close higher on the day
  • Cleveland that Pres. Hammack: I heard from Powell that the Chair is openminded
  • Canada is a set to remove retaliatory tariffs on many US products
  • Trump: I will fire Fed Governor Cook if she does not resign
  • A summary by topic of the speech from Fed chair Powell
  • The full text of the Fed Chair Powell speech at Jackson Hole
  • Fed Powell: Framework calls for a balanced approach. May warrant policy adjustment
  • ECB's Nagel: Expects a micro recession in Germany
  • Fed's Collins: Growth has been slowing but economic fundamentals are relatively solid
  • Ex Fed Pres. Parker Harkers: The data is fuzzy. It is not crystal clear.
  • Canada June retail sales 1.5% vs versus 1.5% expected
  • UBS Global Wealth Management bumps up S&P 500 target for the year
  • investingLive European markets wrap: Jackson Hole wait almost over

Fed Chair Jerome Powell delivered his highly anticipated address at the Jackson Hole symposium, offering markets fresh insight into the central bank’s policy stance heading into the September FOMC meeting. His remarks acknowledged a “curious balance” in the labor market, persistent though tariff-driven inflation pressures, and the Fed’s ongoing challenge of balancing its dual mandate. Powell struck a tone that leaned cautiously dovish, leaving the door open to rate cuts while stressing that decisions remain firmly anchored to incoming data and the evolving economic outlook

Key Highlights

  • Door to September rate cut opened Powell suggested the Fed may consider cutting rates next month, noting both labor demand and supply are slowing. While he stopped short of committing to a move, his tone leaned more dovish.

  • Labor market risks rising Job growth has weakened, with risks of a faster rise in unemployment. Powell stressed the balance of risks has shifted, putting employment on more fragile footing.

  • Tariff-driven inflation likely temporary Tariffs are pushing up prices, but Powell emphasized that these effects are likely short-lived one-time shifts, not a lasting inflation dynamic. Still, he flagged risks from potential wage–price spirals or rising expectations.

  • Fed remains data-driven and independent Powell reaffirmed that the Fed’s path is not preset, with all decisions based on incoming data. He also underscored the Fed’s independence amid external political pressures.

Later, Fed’s Hammack (2026 voter) struck a more hawkish/less dovish tone than markets took from Powell. She emphasized that inflation remains too high and continues to pressure households, requiring the Fed to keep policy mostly restrictive. While she noted the Fed is only modestly restrictive and close to neutral, she stressed that the focus must remain squarely on bringing inflation back toward target. Hammack said she is open-minded going into September, with more data to assess, but underscored that a significant weakening in unemployment would be needed to justify easier policy. For now, she views risks as tilted toward persistence in inflation and signaled caution against easing too quickly.

Although the Fed chair laid the pipe for a cut, US jobs data and US inflation data are to come. The market did start to price in more of a cut. With the futures now pricing in a 90% chance of a cut in September.

US stocks moved sharply higher. Prior to the jump, the NASDAQ index was threatening to make a break below and away from its 200-hour moving average earlier this week (at 21169) and indeed did trade below that moving average level this week. However, with today's gains the price surged back above that key moving average level and also back above its 100-hour moving average at 21368. The buyers are back in job control.

Despite the gains today, the NASDAQ index still closed the lower for the week (-0.58%). The S&P and Dow industrial average did close higher with the Dow industrial average rising by 1.53%. The S&P had a modest gain of 0.27%. The small-cap Russell 2000 of the back of a 3.86% rise today close the week up 3.298%.

European equities closed the session higher across the board, extending gains into the week. The German DAX rose 0.29%, the French CAC gained 0.40%, and the UK FTSE 100 advanced 0.13%, finishing at a new record high. Southern Europe led the day, with Spain’s Ibex up 0.61% and Italy’s FTSE MIB climbing 0.69%, both settling at 17–18 year highs. For the week, momentum was also positive: the DAX added 0.02%, the CAC 0.58%, the FTSE 100 2.0%, the Ibex 0.78%, and the FTSE MIB 1.54%, underscoring broad strength in European markets

US yields move lower with the shorter end influence the most.

  • 2 year yield 3.694%, -9.8 basis points
  • 5 year yield 3.757%, -10.2 basis points
  • 10 year yield 4.253%, -7.8 basis points
  • 30 year yield 4.876% -4.7 basis points

The US dollar moved sharply to the downside along with the lower yields in the expectations of Fed cuts.

  • EUR -1.0%
  • GBP -0.98%
  • JPY -0.83%
  • CHF -0.92%
  • CAD -0.60%
  • AUD -1.07%
  • NZD -0.86%
This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

The yen weakened in Asia with USD/JPY rebounding toward 147.50 in what looked like a retrace of Friday’s Powell-driven drop. Broader FX moves were modest, while upbeat New Zealand retail sales highlighted the boost from lower RBNZ rates. Asia-Pacific equities gained on Powell’s signal that a September Fed cut remains in play.

  • NVDA earnings on Wed. Consider hedging.

The yen led moves in Asia, with USD/JPY climbing from sub-146.75 to around 147.50 before flattening. The move appeared to be a retrace of Friday’s post-Powell drop, rather than a response to fresh news. BOJ Governor Ueda spoke over the weekend and hinted at the potential for further rate hikes, a yen-supportive signal.

The dollar’s strength spilled over modestly into other pairs, with EUR/USD edging lower and early weakness in AUD, NZD, and GBP later retracing. On the data front, New Zealand retail sales surprised to the upside in Q2, a sign that lower RBNZ rates are boosting household consumption and supporting recovery.

Across equities, Asia-Pac markets traded mostly higher, buoyed by expectations that Powell’s Jackson Hole remarks have left the door open to a September Fed rate cut.

Asia-Pac stocks:

  • Australia (S&P/ASX 200) +0.3%
  • Hong Kong (Hang Seng) +1.9%
  • Shanghai Composite +1.2%
  • Japan (Nikkei 225) +0.25%

Cattle and livestock traders will want to note that the first U.S. human screwworm case was confirmed in Maryland. Screwworms are parasitic flies that lay eggs in open wounds, with larvae burrowing into living flesh. In animals, infestations can be fatal if untreated.

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.

title: Gold Price Forecast and Technical Analysis Today
description:
Gold Technical Analysis Today and Price Forecast with tradeCompass (August 25, 2025)

Bullish above: 3414.1 Bearish below: 3409.7 Current price: 3408.5 Primary bias at this moment: Bearish

Gold Futures Performance Snapshot

  • 1 week: +0.80%

  • 1 month: +1.11%

  • 3 months: +1.61%

  • 6 months: +16.41%

  • Year-to-date (YTD): +29.10%

  • 1 year: +35.24%

Gold’s consistent long-term strength — up more than 35% over the past year — provides important context for traders analyzing today’s short-term moves.

Partial Profit Targets for Gold Bearish Traders Today (Once Price Crosses Below 3409.7)

3406.7 – one tick above today’s Value Area Low 3405.7 – aligned with today’s VWAP deviation 3403.2 – next VWAP deviation support 3397.8 – just above the August 22 Value Area Low and Friday’s VWAP

(Swing trader extensions) 3388.8 – above the August 18 Value Area High 3377.5 – above the August 22 Value Area Low

Partial Profit Targets for Gold Bulls Traders Today (If Price Breaks Above 3414.1)

3416.3 – just under Friday’s Point of Control 3417.9 – in line with today’s 3rd upper VWAP deviation 3422.9 – another key level just under Friday’s POC

(Swing trader extensions) 3435.9 – extended VWAP deviation from Friday 3456.1 – broader standard deviation zone

Analysis of Gold Futures Today: Market Context & Directional Bias

At the time of this gold futures analysis today, price sits at 3408.5, slightly under the bearish threshold of 3409.7. That places the market in bearish mode according to the tradeCompass methodology.

If bearish momentum holds, gold futures traders can expect intraday targets near 3406.7 and 3405.7. For bullish traders, price must reclaim 3414.1 to flip sentiment and aim for higher resistance levels.

This close clustering of thresholds and targets suggests a condensed gold trading range today, where sharp moves may occur once either side gains control.

Educational Segment: Why Value Area, VWAP, and Deviations Matter in Gold Trading

  • Value Area: The zone where 70% of trading volume occurs. The Value Area High (VAH) and Value Area Low (VAL) help define likely support and resistance.

  • VWAP (Volume Weighted Average Price): Viewed as “fair value,” it reflects the true balance of price and traded volume. Gold futures above VWAP indicate buyer dominance, below it seller control.

  • Standard Deviations of VWAP: These act like volatility bands. They expand in trending gold markets and contract in consolidations, often marking turning points intraday.

By focusing on these levels, tradeCompass creates an objective trading map for gold futures rather than relying on guesswork.

tradeCompass Methodology & Key Principles for Gold Traders

  • One trade per direction per session.

  • Stops always placed logically, never beyond the opposite threshold.

  • Move stops to entry once the second profit target is reached.

  • Confirmation style is flexible: some traders wait for two candle closes above/below thresholds, others prefer momentum triggers.

This disciplined approach helps gold traders protect capital and stay aligned with market structure.

Conclusion: Gold Price Prediction Today

The gold technical analysis today shows a bearish bias below 3409.7, with first targets at 3406.7 and 3405.7. Bulls must reclaim 3414.1 to shift the market higher. Swing traders may watch for extensions toward 3377.5 on the downside or 3456.1 on the upside.

Despite the intraday bearish lean, gold remains one of the best-performing assets in 2025 — up 29.1% year-to-date and 35.2% over one year — keeping it firmly on the radar for both traders and long-term investors.

For more gold trading ideas, commodity forecasts, and stock/crypto setups, visit investingLive.com and join our Telegram group: ? https://t.me/investingLiveStocks

Trade with discipline, manage risk carefully, and let tradeCompass serve as your daily gold futures map.

This article was written by Itai Levitan at investinglive.com.

title: What are the interest rates expectations after Powell's dovish tilt?
description:
Rate cuts by year-end

  • Fed: 54 bps (85% probability of rate cut at the upcoming meeting)
  • ECB: 9 bps (97% probability of no change at the upcoming meeting)
  • BoE: 12 bps (97% probability of no change at the upcoming meeting)
  • BoC: 23 bps (67% probability of no change at the upcoming meeting)
  • RBA: 37 bps (63% probability of no change at the upcoming meeting)
  • RBNZ: 35 bps (64% probability of rate cut at the upcoming meeting)
  • SNB: 7 bps (91% probability of no change at the upcoming meeting)

Rate hikes by year-end

  • BoJ: 18 bps (88% probability of no change at the upcoming meeting)

Traders reacted strongly to Fed Chair Powell's speech text once they saw the line “nonetheless, with policy in restrictive territory, the baseline outlook and the shifting balance of risks may warrant adjusting our policy stance.” That was interpreted as a dovish tilt and the pricing at some point showed more than 60 bps of easing by year-end and more than 90% of probability of a September cut.

Eventually, things eased up and we got back to the levels seen just before Powell's speech text release. The focus now turns to the NFP report due next week as that's going to be key for interest rates expectations. Strong data might take the probability for a September cut towards a 50/50 chance but will certainly see a more hawkish repricing further down the curve. Soft data, on the other hand, will likely see traders increasing the dovish bets with a third cut by year-end being priced in.

This article was written by Giuseppe Dellamotta at investinglive.com.

title: USDCHF technicals: USDCHF buyers push back above a swing area but sellers still in control
description:
The USDCHF fell sharply on Friday following Powell’s Jackson Hole speech, breaking below the 100- and 200-hour MAs and sliding through the 0.8040–0.8047 swing area. The decline extended under the 0.8017 low of the red box swing area, but sellers couldn’t sustain momentum.

In today’s trading, price has rebounded back inside the red box, though gains are limited. The recovery continues to stall beneath the 0.8040–0.8047 resistance zone, which also lines up with prior swing levels and the 50% midpoint of the July rally. Staying below keeps the bias tilted to the downside.

On the downside, the 0.8017 low of the red box is the first support to watch. A break below the 61.8% retracement of the July rally at 0.8010 would re-open the door for sellers, with the next targets seen near 0.7986–0.7994.

Bottom line: As long as price holds inside the "red box" there is a battle with the buyers and sellers. However, it will would take a move back above 0.8040 to 0.8047, to really start to disappoint sellers. Break 0.8017 and 0.80099 and more doors open for the sellers.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: This situation is reminiscent of the USDCHF movements in March 2020, when the pair also experienced a sharp decline followed by a partial recovery, but the overall trend remained bearish.
explanation: The USDCHF pair experienced a significant drop after Powell's Jackson Hole speech, breaking key support levels and indicating a strong bearish sentiment. Despite a minor recovery in today's trading, the overall trend remains bearish as the price continues to struggle to break through the 0.8040–0.8047 resistance zone. The article suggests that if the price falls below 0.8017, the sellers will regain control, potentially pushing the price further down. This is a bearish scenario, which is why the impact score is negative. However, the author also mentions a 'battle' between buyers and sellers, indicating some level of uncertainty in the market. This is why the confidence level is set to medium. The analysis is based on technical indicators and price action, which are commonly used in forex trading.

title: Kevin O'Leary says he bought Bryant-Jordan card for record-breaking $13 million at auction
description: Canadian investor Kevin O'Leary told CNBC he was one of the buyers of the record-breaking Kobe Bryant and Michael Jordan signed sports card.
patterns: Previous record-breaking purchases of sports memorabilia have not had a direct impact on financial markets.
explanation: Kevin O'Leary's purchase of the Kobe Bryant and Michael Jordan signed sports card for a record-breaking $13 million is a significant event within the collectibles and sports memorabilia market. However, it is unlikely to have a direct impact on broader financial markets. The purchase demonstrates the high value attached to rare sports memorabilia and the willingness of wealthy individuals to invest in these items. This could potentially influence the prices of similar items in the future. Nevertheless, this is a niche market and its influence over larger sectors such as stocks, bonds, or commodities is minimal. This event could, however, be indicative of the overall health of the luxury goods and collectibles market, which can sometimes be a reflection of broader economic trends. But, given its specificity, the confidence level that this event would influence broader financial markets is high.

title: Temu’s parent company is trying to fend off competition from Alibaba — but it’s a costly fight
description: PDD is spending more to boost revenue, and its stock is rising as investors seem satisfied with the trade off.
patterns: Similar to Amazon's spending spree in the early 2000s to fend off competitors and establish dominance in the market.
explanation: PDD, the parent company of Temu, is in a tough battle with Alibaba, one of the largest e-commerce platforms in the world. To fend off competition, PDD is spending more to boost its revenue. This move is causing a rise in its stock as investors seem to be satisfied with the trade-off. While this strategy might help PDD in the short term, it could potentially lead to financial instability in the long term due to increased expenditure. The competition with Alibaba, a well-established and financially robust company, could further strain PDD's resources. However, if PDD's strategy pays off, it could secure a larger market share, which would be beneficial for its long-term growth. Investors seem to be optimistic about this strategy, as evidenced by the rise in PDD's stock. But the high cost and the strong competition from Alibaba make this a risky move, hence the negative impact score.

The increased spending could potentially impact the company's profitability if it fails to significantly increase its market share or if the competition intensifies further. Therefore, the impact on the market is moderately bearish, reflecting the potential risks associated with the company's current strategy. The affected markets include the e-commerce sector, the tech stock market, and more specifically, the China market where both PDD and Alibaba operate.

title: Furniture tariffs will be imposed as part of national security investigations into lumber
description:
The Trump administration will say section 232 tariff at 15%. The tariff action is part of "national security investigation into lumber".

I guess the price to build houses might go higher as the US faces a supply/cost issue in housing.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to previous instances when tariffs were imposed on steel and aluminum imports under section 232, the cost of raw materials increased, impacting related industries.
explanation: The imposition of a 15% tariff as part of a national security investigation into lumber indicates a potential increase in the cost of lumber. This is likely to have a significant negative impact on sectors that heavily rely on lumber, such as housing, construction, and furniture. As the cost of raw material increases, the cost of production for these industries will also rise, which could lead to increased prices for consumers. This could potentially slow down the housing market, as the cost to build houses may become prohibitively high. Furthermore, it could also lead to a decrease in demand for furniture and other goods made from lumber, as prices rise. The high confidence level is due to the direct correlation between tariffs and increased costs, which has been observed in similar situations in the past.

title: Will Figma’s stock keep riding the AI hype? Wall Street isn’t so sure.
description: Figma has been a rare bright spot in a tough software market, but its premium stock price is giving some Wall Street analysts pause.
patterns: Historically, overhyped tech stocks have experienced a correction after initial excitement dies down. Examples include the dot-com bubble in the late 90s and early 2000s.
explanation: Figma, despite its success in a challenging software market, is causing some hesitation among Wall Street analysts due to its high stock price. This could indicate a potential overvaluation of the stock, which is often followed by a market correction. The current hype around AI technology may be inflating Figma's stock price beyond its actual value, creating an unstable situation. When the excitement around a new technology or market sector wanes, it's common to see a correction in stock prices. This has been seen in the past with the dot-com bubble and more recently with certain cryptocurrency stocks. Therefore, while Figma has shown strong performance, the inflated stock price and potential overvaluation could lead to a negative impact on its stock in the near future.

title: Will Figma’s stock keep riding the AI hype? Wall Street isn’t so sure.

explanation: Figma's stock has been performing exceptionally well in a tough software market, which has been a relief for investors. However, its premium stock price is causing some concern among Wall Street analysts. This concern is rooted in the fear that the stock's value is being artificially inflated by the hype around AI, rather than being based on the company's actual performance or potential. If this is the case, there could be a correction in the future, which would result in a drop in the stock's price. This is similar to what happened during the tech bubble in the late 1990s. Therefore, while the AI industry is indeed promising, it's crucial to ensure that the stock prices of companies in this sector reflect their true value and not just the hype surrounding the technology.

explanation: Figma, a software company, has been performing well in a challenging market, but its elevated stock price is causing concern among some Wall Street analysts. This is indicative of the market's uncertainty about the sustainability of the company's current stock price. The AI hype has been a major driver for tech stocks, including Figma. However, the question remains whether the company can justify its high valuation with solid financial performance and growth. If not, the stock could potentially face a correction. This has happened before in the tech sector, most notably during the Dotcom Bubble in the late 90s and early 2000s, when many internet-based companies were highly overvalued due to hype. When these companies failed to deliver on their promises, their stocks crashed, leading to a market correction. Therefore, while the AI hype may currently be benefiting Figma, it also poses a risk if the company fails to meet the high expectations set by its stock price.

title: EURUSD technicals: EURUSD trades to a new low for the day
description:
The EURUSD has slipped to a new session low, extending what remains a relatively tight trading range. So far, the range for the day measures just 47 pips, still well short of the 88-pip average.

From a technical perspective, the pair is moving further away from the swing area between 1.1692 and 1.17028, leaving buyers with less near-term support to lean against and giving sellers some additional confidence. The focus now shifts to a cluster of downside targets, including:

  • 200-hour moving average at 1.16674

  • 61.8% retracement of the move since the July 1 high at 1.16615

  • 100-hour moving average at 1.16522

That confluence of levels represents a critical support zone. A break below would undo much of Friday’s upside momentum, disappointing buyers who stepped in above those same technical markers on the run to the upside.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to previous instances when the EURUSD pair moved away from the swing area, it typically led to increased selling pressure.

From a technical perspective, the pair is moving further away from the swing area between 1.1692 and 1.17028, which can be interpreted as a bearish signal. The focus now shifts to a cluster of downside targets, including the 200-hour moving average at 1.16674, the 61.8% retracement of the move since the July 1 high at 1.16615, and the 100-hour moving average at 1.16522. These levels represent a critical support zone. A break below these levels would undo much of Friday’s upside momentum, disappointing buyers who stepped in above those same technical markers on the run to the upside. This suggests a negative or bearish impact on the EURUSD market.

title: USDJPY stretches above 200 hour MA. Tests 100 hour MA.
description:
The USDJPY stretched higher as European traders exit the day.

The move to the upside took the price above the 200-hour moving average at 147.49, and up to the 100-hour moving average at 147.646. The price has stalled against that higher moving average as traders debate higher or lower and fight it out.

On a break above the 100 hour MA, the 38.2% retracement and swing area above and below 148.000 becomes the target. Traders who sold after Powell's speech would be disappointed as the buyers take back more control.

On the downside, if the 200-hour moving average is broken with momentum, look for the 147.075 as the next target area followed by the swing area 146.61to 146.75

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to previous instances when the USDJPY broke above the 200-hour moving average, a potential shift in control from sellers to buyers is observed.
explanation: The article discusses the recent movement of the USDJPY currency pair, which has seen a rise above the 200-hour moving average, indicating a potential bullish trend. The price has reached the 100-hour moving average at 147.646, a point at which traders are debating whether the price will move higher or lower. If the price breaks above the 100-hour moving average, the next target would be the 38.2% retracement and swing area above and below 148.000. This would disappoint traders who sold after Powell's speech, as it would indicate buyers regaining control. However, if the price breaks below the 200-hour moving average with momentum, the next target would be 147.075, followed by the swing area 146.61 to 146.75. The impact of these potential movements on the market is moderately bullish, assuming buyers gain control.

title: More Trump News: Weighs visa sanctions for EU and EU members state officials
description:
The whack-a-mole continues as Trump administration weighs visa sanctions for EU an EU member state officials over the blocs digital services act.

Trade is complicated, and I am sure the process will just go on and on. So just when you think it's over, it's just begun.

On other topics:

  • Trump says he discussed the colorization with Russian Pres. Putin. He thinks Russia and China would be willing to do it
  • On China, says that China Pres. Xi wants him to come to China.
  • Trump will allow China students to come in
  • China has to give us magnets. If they do not, charge them 200% tariff or something
  • At some point, he will go to China.
  • Maybe he will go with South Korea Pres. Lee.

Meanwhile:

  • Ukraine Zelenskyy said that he had a good meeting with US envoy Kellogg.
  • Values US readiness to be part of Ukraine's security architecture

Trump this morning said that the US would provide secondary security measures.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the previous trade wars initiated by the Trump administration against China, this move could potentially escalate into a full-blown trade war with the EU.
explanation: The Trump administration's consideration of visa sanctions against EU and EU member state officials over the bloc's digital services act could potentially strain relations and lead to retaliatory measures. This could negatively impact the EU market and tech sector. Furthermore, the potential 200% tariff on China if they don't supply magnets to the US could escalate trade tensions, affecting the metals market. On the other hand, Trump's willingness to allow Chinese students to study in the US and his potential visit to China could be seen as positive signs for easing tensions. However, the overall impact of these policies is still uncertain, hence the medium confidence level. The potential for increased geopolitical tensions could lead to market volatility, negatively impacting investor sentiment.

title: What's likely behind the 2% drop in Starbucks stock during Monday's session
description: Every weekday, the Investing Club releases the Homestretch; an actionable afternoon update just in time for the last hour of trading.
patterns: Similar to the historical pattern when Starbucks shares fell due to unexpected negative earnings reports.
explanation: The 2% drop in Starbucks stock during Monday's trading session is likely due to a combination of factors. One possible cause could be a negative reaction to recent news or events related to the company. For instance, if Starbucks announced lower than expected earnings, or if there were negative reports about the company's operations, this could lead to a sell-off of the stock. Another possible reason could be broader market trends. If the overall market is down, many stocks, including Starbucks, could be affected. Additionally, investor sentiment towards the consumer discretionary sector, which Starbucks is a part of, could also play a role. If investors are turning away from this sector in favor of more defensive sectors, Starbucks' stock price could be negatively impacted. Finally, it's also possible that the drop is simply due to normal fluctuations in the stock market. Stocks often rise and fall in the short term due to a variety of factors, including changes in investor sentiment, market trends, and company-specific news. Without more specific information, it's impossible to say for sure why Starbucks' stock price fell on this particular day.

Finally, any recent company-specific news or events could also be contributing to the stock's decline. It's important for investors to consider all these factors when analyzing the stock's performance.

title: Crude oil futures settle at $64.80
description:
Crude oil futures are settling at $64.80 up $1.14 or 1.79%. The high for the day reached $65.10. The low was at $63.53.

On the daily chart, the price has moved back above its 100-day moving average at $64.29, giving buyers a short-term edge. The market is now testing a swing area between $63.61 and $65.27 (see red circles on the chart). A sustained break above this zone would shift focus toward the 200-day moving average at $67.46, with interim resistance near $67.00.

That said, the pair has seen choppy trading around both the 100- and 200-day MAs in recent years, with repeated breaks in both directions. Overall the highs are lower as are the lows suggesting more of a downward bias. However there are fits of spikes to the upside as well.

For now, however, as long as the price holds above the 100-day average, the near-term bias tilts in favor of buyers, keeping upside targets in play.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Historically, crude oil prices have seen spikes and drops around the 100- and 200-day moving averages, indicating a volatile market.
explanation: The crude oil futures are settling at $64.80, which is an increase of $1.14 or 1.79%. This indicates a bullish market with the price moving back above its 100-day moving average at $64.29. This gives buyers a short-term edge and keeps upside targets in play as long as the price holds above this average. The market is now testing a swing area between $63.61 and $65.27. A sustained break above this zone would shift focus toward the 200-day moving average at $67.46. However, the market has seen choppy trading around both the 100- and 200-day MAs in recent years, with repeated breaks in both directions. This suggests a pattern of volatility, with a downward bias overall, but with occasional spikes to the upside. In conclusion, the near-term bias tilts in favor of buyers, but the overall trend suggests a more bearish market.

title: Why do so many investors think the stock market is forming a bubble?
description: A big increase in predictions that a bubble is about to burst actually makes it less likely that one will, contrarians say
patterns: The dot-com bubble in the late 1990s, the housing market bubble in 2007
explanation: The perception of a bubble in the stock market can lead to a self-fulfilling prophecy, where investors pull out of the market due to fear, causing prices to drop. However, the contrarian view mentioned in the article suggests that an increase in predictions of a bubble actually makes it less likely to occur. This is because these predictions can cause investors to act more cautiously, potentially preventing the market from overheating and forming a bubble. It should be noted that predicting market bubbles is notoriously difficult and not all bubbles lead to crashes. While the perception of a bubble could have a negative impact on market sentiment in the short term, the contrarian view suggests it could actually stabilize the market in the long term.

title: Why do so many investors think the stock market is forming a bubble?
description: A big increase in predictions that a bubble is about to burst actually makes it less likely that one will, contrarians say
patterns: The dot-com bubble in the late 90s, the housing market bubble in 2008
explanation: The fear of a potential market bubble could lead to a bearish sentiment among investors. The idea that a large number of investors predicting a bubble actually makes it less likely to occur is a contrarian view, suggesting that the market may behave in the opposite way to the majority opinion. This is because if a significant number of investors believe the market is overvalued and start selling their stocks, it could lead to a decrease in stock prices. However, it's also possible that this contrarian view could lead to complacency, as investors may believe the market is 'safe' from a bubble due to the high number of predictions. This could potentially lead to an actual bubble forming if investors continue to overvalue stocks. It's a complex situation with many variables, hence the medium confidence level.

title: Why do so many investors think the stock market is forming a bubble?
description: A big increase in predictions that a bubble is about to burst actually makes it less likely that one will, contrarians say
patterns: Similar to the dotcom bubble of the late 90s and the housing market bubble of 2007-2008
explanation: The article suggests that there is a growing consensus among investors that the stock market is forming a bubble. This belief is often rooted in the observation of rapid market gains that seem disconnected from underlying economic realities. However, the article also points out that contrarian investors argue that a widespread belief in a bubble actually makes it less likely to occur, as it could lead to more cautious investment behavior, which could in turn stabilize the market. Still, the mere perception of a bubble can create a sense of uncertainty and risk aversion, which might lead to a slowdown in market activity and a moderate negative impact on market performance. Therefore, while the impact isn't necessarily large, the news does carry a slightly bearish sentiment.

title: Could your financial adviser’s politics hurt your investments?
description: What to keep in mind when mixing politics and portfolios.
patterns: Historically, political bias in financial advice has led to skewed investment decisions, most notably during the 2016 US Presidential Election
explanation: The political affiliations of a financial adviser can potentially influence their investment advice and consequently, the performance of your portfolio. This is because an adviser's political bias can lead to subjective assessments of market trends, economic policies, and fiscal risks. For instance, an adviser with conservative political views might overemphasize the risks of progressive economic policies, thus skewing their investment advice towards more conservative assets. Conversely, an adviser with progressive political views might downplay the risks of progressive economic policies, thus skewing their investment advice towards more aggressive assets. This could lead to sub-optimal investment decisions that do not align with the actual market trends and risks. Therefore, it is important for investors to be aware of their adviser's political affiliations and to ensure that their investment advice is based on objective market analyses rather than political biases.

title: Could your financial adviser’s politics hurt your investments?
description: What to keep in mind when mixing politics and portfolios.
patterns: Historically, political bias has influenced investment decisions, often leading to sub-optimal outcomes.
explanation: The potential influence of a financial adviser's political views on investment decisions can create a bias that may negatively impact the performance of the portfolio. This is because political views can cloud judgement and lead to decisions that are not based on a rational analysis of the market. For example, an adviser with strong political views may favor companies that align with their political beliefs over others that may offer better returns. This could lead to a lack of diversification in the portfolio, increasing the risk of loss. Moreover, the adviser may also have a bias towards certain sectors or markets, which could lead to missed opportunities in other areas. Therefore, it's crucial for individuals to ensure that their adviser's political views do not influence their investment decisions and to consider seeking a second opinion if necessary.

title: Could your financial adviser’s politics hurt your investments?
description: What to keep in mind when mixing politics and portfolios.
patterns: There have been instances in the past where political bias of financial advisors have affected the investment decisions, leading to suboptimal returns.
explanation: The political leanings of a financial adviser could potentially impact the advice they give and, consequently, the performance of your investments. If an adviser's political bias leads them to favor certain sectors or companies based on those leanings rather than on sound financial analysis, it could result in suboptimal investment decisions. For example, an adviser with strong environmental leanings might avoid oil and gas stocks, potentially missing out on profitable opportunities. Similarly, an adviser with a conservative bias might avoid investing in emerging technologies or industries, which could also limit potential returns. Therefore, it's crucial for investors to be aware of their adviser's potential biases and ensure that their advice is based on comprehensive financial analysis rather than personal political beliefs. This news is a reminder for investors to be vigilant about potential biases in financial advice, which could have a slight negative impact on market sentiment overall.

title: USD buying continues its march. New highs for the greenback versus most major currencies
description:
Dollar buying is continuing in all the major currencies. The greenback is making new highs versus all but the AUD as the day takes toward the close.

EURUSD: The EURUSD has broken decisively lower, falling beneath both the 200- and 100-hour moving averages in the past two hours without much corrective retracement. Selling pressure has also pushed the pair below the converged 100- and 200-bar moving averages on the 4-hour chart near 1.1640, as well as the 50% midpoint of the July trading range at 1.16098.

The latest low touched 1.16019, putting the spotlight on last week’s low at 1.15816 and the prior week’s low at 1.15885. Those levels now form the next key downside targets that traders will be eyeing.

USDJPY: The USDJPY has pushed back above both its 200- and 100-hour moving averages at 147.49 and 147.646, easing some of the bearish pressure from Friday’s sharp decline. The focus now shifts to a swing area between 147.95 and 148.166, which also includes the 38.2% retracement of the August trading range at 148.00. A break through that zone would strengthen the bullish bias and open the door to further recovery.

GBPUSD: The GBPUSD has slipped back below its 100-hour moving average and the 50% midpoint of the July trading range at 1.3464, shifting the near-term bias in favor of sellers. Holding below that level will be key in keeping downside momentum intact.

On the downside, the 100-day moving average at 1.34214 is the next critical target. Last Friday—just ahead of Powell’s speech—the pair briefly fell below that level for the first time since August 7, only to snap back higher on the headlines. A return below the 100-day average this time would add to the bearish tilt and reinforce seller control.

Already, today’s break beneath both the 200- and 100-hour moving averages has tilted the short-term bias more firmly toward the downside.

USDCAD: The USDCAD is rebounding from support between 1.38127 and 1.38315, with the pair now trading near 1.3860. On the upside, the immediate target comes in at the August 1 high at 1.38785, followed by a swing area between 1.3891 and 1.3904. Beyond that sits the 38.2% retracement at 1.39229—a level that capped gains just ahead of Powell’s speech on Friday, when sellers reemerged.

On the downside, it would take a break back below 1.38127 and the rising 100-bar MA on the 4-hour chart at 1.38018 to shift the bias more convincingly toward sellers. Until then, buyers maintain the near-term edge.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the dollar's rise in 2014 when it gained against most major currencies due to strong economic data.
explanation: The US Dollar is showing strength against most major currencies, as noted in the article. This is primarily due to the continued buying of the USD in the market. The EURUSD has broken decisively lower, falling beneath both the 200- and 100-hour moving averages, indicating a bearish trend. The USDJPY has pushed back above its 200- and 100-hour moving averages, easing some of the bearish pressure and opening the door to further recovery. The GBPUSD has slipped back below its 100-hour moving average, shifting the near-term bias in favor of sellers. The USDCAD is rebounding from support, indicating a bullish trend. Overall, these movements suggest a strong position for the USD in the forex market, which could lead to potential investment opportunities in favor of the USD. It's important to monitor these trends closely as they can impact other financial markets and economic indicators.

title: investingLive Americas FX news wrap 25 Aug:The USD moved steadily higher in the US session
description:
• US stocks close lower. S&P and Dow stay in negative territory. Nasdaq loses gains
  • Trump says he thinks a deal has been done with South Korea
  • USD buying continues its march. New highs for the greenback versus most major currencies
  • Crude oil futures settle at $64.80
  • Canadian/US officials are to meet after Canada removes some tariffs
  • More Trump News: Weighs visa sanctions for EU and EU members state officials
  • Did Powell finally give in to pressure from Trump?
  • The Trump News: He is speaking on various topics. Here is the summary.
  • Furniture tariffs will be imposed as part of national security investigations into lumber
  • US new sales July 0.652M versus 0.630M estimate
  • Trump: I paid zero for Intel. It is worth approxiamately $11B
  • Kevin Hassett: The Pres feels it would be great if he could build a sovereign wealth fund
  • The USD is mostly higher to kickstart the new trading day/week
  • investingLive European markets wrap: Dollar breather as markets settle down after Friday

The USD was little changed to start the US session. London was off for a summer holiday long weekend. As a result activity was limited. The USD was still a bit higher after the sharp sell off after the Friday speech from Fed Chair Powell speech.

Today yields were a bit higher to start the day and although they did not run to the upside (and came back down toward the end of the day),, the USD was a different story. After starting off slow, it started to creep higher and that move did not really abate (although it was orderly) for most of the US session.

Near the end of day, the greenback is higher vs all the major currencies with the EUR the weakest

  • EUR: +0.78%
  • JPY +0.50%
  • GBP +0.48%
  • CHF +0.55%
  • CAD +0.20%
  • AUD +0.08%
  • NZD +0.29%

Technically, speaking, some of the key levels to eye going into the new trading day:

EURUSD: The EURUSD has broken decisively lower, falling beneath both the 200- and 100-hour moving averages in the past two hours without much corrective retracement. Selling pressure has also pushed the pair below the converged 100- and 200-bar moving averages on the 4-hour chart near 1.1640, as well as the 50% midpoint of the July trading range at 1.16098.

The latest low touched 1.16019, putting the spotlight on last week’s low at 1.15816 and the prior week’s low at 1.15885. Those levels now form the next key downside targets that traders will be eyeing.

USDJPY: The USDJPY has pushed back above both its 200- and 100-hour moving averages at 147.49 and 147.646, easing some of the bearish pressure from Friday’s sharp decline. The focus now shifts to a swing area between 147.95 and 148.166, which also includes the 38.2% retracement of the August trading range at 148.00. A break through that zone would strengthen the bullish bias and open the door to further recovery.

GBPUSD: The GBPUSD has slipped back below its 100-hour moving average and the 50% midpoint of the July trading range at 1.3464, shifting the near-term bias in favor of sellers. Holding below that level will be key in keeping downside momentum intact.

On the downside, the 100-day moving average at 1.34214 is the next critical target. Last Friday—just ahead of Powell’s speech—the pair briefly fell below that level for the first time since August 7, only to snap back higher on the headlines. A return below the 100-day average this time would add to the bearish tilt and reinforce seller control.

Already, today’s break beneath both the 200- and 100-hour moving averages has tilted the short-term bias more firmly toward the downside.

USDCAD: The USDCAD is rebounding from support between 1.38127 and 1.38315, with the pair now trading near 1.3860. On the upside, the immediate target comes in at the August 1 high at 1.38785, followed by a swing area between 1.3891 and 1.3904. Beyond that sits the 38.2% retracement at 1.39229—a level that capped gains just ahead of Powell’s speech on Friday, when sellers reemerged.

On the downside, it would take a break back below 1.38127 and the rising 100-bar MA on the 4-hour chart at 1.38018 to shift the bias more convincingly toward sellers. Until then, buyers maintain the near-term edge.

Meanwhile, looking at the US debt market, the yields are higher but nearer the lows for the day vs. the highs.

  • 2 year yield 3.725%, +3.8 basis points
  • 5 year yield 3.785%, +2.8 basis points
  • 10 year yield 4.277%, +1.9 basis points
  • 30 year yield, +0.8 basis points

The only economic released today was new home sales for July 2025 which came better than expected at 0.652M, slightly above the 0.630M estimate, though down -0.6% on the month versus a 4.1% gain in June. The prior month was revised higher to 0.656M from 0.627M. On a year-over-year basis, sales fell -8.2%. The median sales price declined to $403,800, down -0.8% from June and -5.9% from a year ago ($429,000), while the average price slipped to $487,300, -3.6% lower than June and -5.0% below July 2024. Supply eased to 9.2 months from 9.8, suggesting some inventory tightening. Mortgage rates during the reporting period were above 6.75%, though the recent dip back toward 6.5% was not reflected in these numbers. Builders continue to discount prices to attract buyers.

US stocks got off to a slow start and although the NASDAQ index did trade in positive territory, it closed lower on the day. It was still better than the down S&P which never traded in positive territory for the entire day.

The final numbers are showing:

  • Dow industrial average -349.27 points or -0.77% at 45282.47
  • S&P index down -27.59 points or -0.43% at 6439.32
  • Nasdaq index down -47.24 points or -0.22% at 21449.2

The small-cap Russell 2000 fell -22.75 points or -0.96% at 2339.1734.

Trump met with South Korean Pres. Lee and said that the meeting went well and they likely have a deal done. Details are forthcoming, however reports were that South Korea would purchase US defense, and potentially aid in shipbuilding.

This article was written by Greg Michalowski at investinglive.com.

title: Powell just gambled big in Jackson Hole. Will it pay off?
description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on Friday opened the door to an interest-rate cut, surprising many economists.
patterns: Similar to the Fed's decision to cut interest rates in July 2019, which led to a short-term increase in stock market performance but also raised concerns about the health of the economy.
explanation: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's decision to open the door to an interest-rate cut can be seen as a gamble. This move suggests that the Fed is concerned about the state of the economy and is willing to take measures to stimulate growth. While this could lead to a short-term increase in stock market performance, as investors often react positively to lower interest rates, it could also raise concerns about the health of the economy. Lower interest rates can stimulate borrowing and investing, but they also suggest that the economy might not be strong enough to withstand higher rates. Additionally, this move could weaken the dollar in the forex market, as lower interest rates often lead to a less attractive currency for foreign investors. Therefore, while this move could have positive short-term effects, it could also signal potential long-term economic instability.

However, they can also signal that the economy is in a weaker state, which could lead to a negative market reaction. In this case, the surprise move has the potential to unsettle investors who were not expecting such a decision. On the other hand, if the cut leads to the desired economic stimulation, it could boost the markets in the long-term. The impact on sectors such as banking and finance could be mixed. While lower interest rates can squeeze banks' net interest margins, they can also lead to increased loan volumes. The overall impact is therefore slightly bearish in the short-term, but could potentially be positive in the long-term if the rate cut successfully stimulates the economy.

title: Heads up: French government faces collapse as Bayrou risks budget confidence vote (Sept 8)
description:
France’s minority government faces collapse as PM Bayrou calls a September 8 confidence vote on sweeping budget cuts, with major opposition parties already lined up against him. Political uncertainty rattled markets, pushing French bond spreads wider and knocking the CAC 40 lower.

-

France’s minority government faces a severe test after Prime Minister François Bayrou announced a September 8 confidence vote on his €44 billion budget-cutting plan. The far-right National Rally, Greens and Socialists all signalled they will oppose him, making the government’s collapse increasingly likely.

If Bayrou loses, his cabinet will fall, forcing President Emmanuel Macron to either appoint a new prime minister, keep Bayrou as caretaker, or call fresh elections. Political turmoil has already unsettled markets: French bond spreads over German Bunds widened 5bp to the highest since mid-June, while the CAC 40 dropped 1.6%.

Macron has already lost one prime minister to a budget no-confidence vote last year, underscoring the fragility of his administration. Bayrou admitted the gamble was risky but said failure to act on France’s debt burden—5.8% of GDP in 2024, nearly double EU limits—was riskier still. Even survival in September would not guarantee passage of the budget itself, which will face another vote later in the year.

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.
patterns: Political instability often leads to market volatility, as seen in Greece during its debt crisis in 2010-2012, and Italy during its political crisis in 2018.
explanation: The potential collapse of the French government has led to a significant increase in political risk, which is typically negative for financial markets. Prime Minister François Bayrou's call for a confidence vote on his €44 billion budget-cutting plan has already unsettled markets, with French bond spreads over German Bunds widening and the CAC 40 index dropping. If Bayrou loses the vote, the ensuing political turmoil could lead to further market instability. Furthermore, even if Bayrou survives the confidence vote, the budget will face another vote later in the year, which could prolong the period of uncertainty. This situation is reminiscent of past instances where political crises have led to market volatility, such as Greece's debt crisis and Italy's political crisis.

title: Small packages, big problem: global post grinds to a halt on U.S. tariff rule.
description:
European and Asian postal services are suspending U.S. shipments as the $800 de minimis tariff exemption ends, threatening the flow of small parcels worldwide. The move hits discount retailers like Shein and Temu, while leaving millions of cross-border gift and e-commerce deliveries in limbo.

-

Postal agencies across Europe and Asia are pausing or halting shipments to the U.S. as the de minimis tariff exemption, which allowed goods worth $800 or less to enter tariff-free, expires this week.

Trump revoked the exemption for Chinese parcels earlier this year, and as of August 29 it applies to all countries, leaving international carriers scrambling to adjust. At least 16 European postal services

  • including Royal Mail, Deutsche Post, Bpost, and France’s La Poste
  • plus several Asian carriers such as Japan Post, and Australia Post

have temporarily suspended or restricted deliveries to the U.S., citing unclear guidance from U.S. Customs and lack of time to implement compliance systems.

The disruption threatens the flow of hundreds of millions of small parcels, from personal gifts to e-commerce shipments. Last year, 1.3 billion packages entered the U.S. under de minimis, about 60% from China. Discount retailers like Shein and Temu are already facing sharply higher costs as their business models relied heavily on the exemption.

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the U.S.-China trade war in 2018-2019, which led to increased tariffs and disrupted global supply chains.
explanation: The end of the de minimis tariff exemption, which allowed goods worth $800 or less to enter the U.S. tariff-free, is causing a significant disruption in global postal services. Postal agencies across Europe and Asia, including major carriers like Royal Mail, Deutsche Post, and Japan Post, have suspended or restricted deliveries to the U.S. due to unclear guidance from U.S. Customs and insufficient time to implement compliance systems. This development threatens the flow of hundreds of millions of small parcels worldwide, from personal gifts to e-commerce shipments. Notably, discount retailers like Shein and Temu, whose business models relied heavily on this exemption, are expected to face sharply higher costs. Last year, 1.3 billion packages entered the U.S. under de minimis, about 60% from China. This change could severely impact global e-commerce and retail sectors, potentially leading to higher prices for consumers and lower profit margins for businesses.

title: investingLive Asia-Pacific FX news wrap: Trump moves to fire Cook, gold jumps
description:
Trump’s move to fire Fed Governor Lisa Cook via social media sent the U.S. dollar tumbling, with gold surging above USD 3,385 and safe-haven flows boosting JPY and CHF. The legality of the firing was quickly questioned, fuelling concerns over Fed independence and adding to pressure on the dollar.

  • Japan finance minister Kato: Alarmed over FX moves, including those driven by speculators
  • RBA August minutes: Some further reduction in cash rate likely to be needed in coming year
  • ICYMI - The USD has been smashed lower on the news that Trump has fired Fed Governor Cook
  • PBOC sets USD/ CNY reference rate for today at 7.1188 (vs. estimate at 7.1670)
  • Trump threatens tariffs on countries with digital taxes
  • Senior Chinese trade negotiator heads to Washington for first round of talks
  • Gold, yen, EUR, CHF all continue to move higher as the US dollar gets Trump-trashed
  • The USD has been slammed lower on the news of Trump moving to fire Fed Governor Cook
  • Trump says he is removing Fed Governor Cook
  • Japanese Services PPI (July 2025) +2.9% y/y (expected +3.2%)
  • US secures $50B Boeing & GE Aerospace deal with Korean Air
  • Fed's Williams does not comment on monetary policy outlook in his speech
  • UK shop prices jump most since March 2024, fuelling Bank of England inflation fears
  • UBS calls Fed easing from September, boosting equities outlook
  • Small packages, big problem: global post grinds to a halt on U.S. tariff rule.
  • Interactive Brokers will replace Walgreens Boots Alliance in the S&P 500
  • Heads up: French government faces collapse as Bayrou risks budget confidence vote (Sept 8)
  • ICYMI - Barclays sees two Fed cuts in 2025, warns of 50% U.S. recession risk under Trump
  • Bitcoin - the struggle continues (back under US$110K)
  • investingLive Americas FX news wrap 25 Aug:The USD moved steadily higher in the US session
  • New York Fed President John Williams is speaking Monday evening, US time
  • Dallas Fed President Lorie Logan doesn't drop any clues on a September interest rate cut
  • US stocks close lower. S&P and Dow stay in negative territory. Nasdaq loses gains
  • Trump says he thinks a deal has been done with South Korea

Trump posted a letter on his social media platform announcing the firing of Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook, a move that sent the dollar plunging and gold surging above USD 3,385. His attempt to oust Cook undercut the USD on two fronts: by signalling his desire to stack the Fed with loyalists to force rate cuts, and by undermining confidence in the Bank’s independence.

The dollar weakened broadly, with gold the standout gainer and safe-haven flows into JPY and CHF driving USD/JPY down to 147.00 and USD/CHF to 0.8030. EUR, GBP, AUD, and NZD also advanced. The dollar later clawed back some ground, though mainly as modest retracement.

Legal questions quickly followed Trump’s post, with debate over whether he has the authority to dismiss a Fed governor at all. Powell could set a precedent by insisting Cook remain during the challenge, while some suggested a middle ground of her staying on but not voting until the courts decide. More cynical takes held that Trump’s social media theatrics were designed to stir dollar and gold moves for the benefit/profit of his circle.

Other developments were overshadowed by the firing saga. New York Fed President John Williams spoke but offered no policy outlook, while RBA minutes read as less hawkish than expected. Trump threatened countries that have digital taxes with ‘subsequent additional tariffs’ on their goods if those nations do not remove such legislation.

This article was written by Eamonn Sheridan at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to previous instances of political interference in monetary policy, such as President Nixon pressuring Fed Chairman Arthur Burns in the 1970s.
explanation: The news of President Trump's attempt to fire Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook has caused significant upheaval in financial markets. The US Dollar has tumbled, while safe-haven assets like gold, JPY, and CHF have seen a surge. This is due to the perceived undermining of the Federal Reserve's independence, a crucial pillar for market stability. Moreover, the legality of the firing has been questioned, adding to market uncertainty and further pressuring the dollar. The move is seen as an attempt by Trump to stack the Fed with loyalists to force rate cuts, potentially leading to an overheated economy. Additionally, this could be seen as a strategic move to manipulate dollar and gold prices for the benefit of his circle, further eroding market confidence. Other market developments were overshadowed by this event, highlighting its significance. Therefore, the overall impact of this news is highly bearish for the dollar and bullish for safe-haven assets.

title: Japan trade negotiator says "no comment" on supposed $550 billion US investment
description:
• Will continue to demand presidential order to cut US tariffs on Japanese goods soon
  • No comment on Lutnick's comments about $550 billion package of US-bound investment

In case you missed it, Lutnick yesterday said this:

"The Japanese agreement, which we're going to announce later this week, that's $550 billion at the hand of Donald Trump."

Akazawa is expected to make a trip to Washington to formalise the trade framework agreement, one that sees the US putting 15% tariffs on Japan while Tokyo supposedly commits to $550 billion in government-backed loans and guarantees in the US. However, there aren't any details on the latter and so far there has been a lack of confirmation from Japan as well - as evident by the above.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
patterns: Similar to the US-China trade negotiations, the announcement of a large investment package could signal a significant breakthrough in trade talks.
explanation: The news indicates that there might be a significant trade agreement between the US and Japan, with Japan supposedly committing to $550 billion in government-backed loans and guarantees in the US. However, the Japanese trade negotiator has not confirmed these details yet, which leads to some uncertainty. If confirmed, this could have a substantial impact on both economies, potentially leading to increased investment and economic growth. The Japanese negotiator's demand for a presidential order to cut US tariffs on Japanese goods soon could also indicate that Japan is seeking more favorable trade conditions, which could further boost economic activity. However, the current 15% tariffs that the US is imposing on Japan could be a potential obstacle in the negotiations. The final outcome of these trade talks could have a significant impact on the markets, particularly in sectors involved in US-Japan trade.

title: A near empty calendar day beckons in European trading again
description:
The only item on the economic calendar in Europe today is the French consumer confidence report for July. That will be due at 0645 GMT. Besides that, it's pretty much an empty calendar day once again. However, that is not to say that traders and investors won't have much to digest.

The big news since overnight trading was US president Trump announcing that he will fire Fed governor Cook. That sent the dollar spiraling lower initially before traders mapped out the feasibility of Trump's decision. There will be legal hurdles to get through that could take some time but for now at best, Cook may be incapacitated in her position as Fed governor.

Besides that, there is also the further steepening in the US yield curve post-Jackson Hole here. It is one that is quietly making waves but worth noting in case it becomes of something in the weeks ahead.

For today, it seems like it might be another quieter session as markets also calm down following the Trump drama. In Europe, things will only really heat up on Friday with inflation numbers to go alongside month-end flows. So, do be wary about that.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
patterns: Historically, announcements of changes in key positions within the Federal Reserve often lead to short-term volatility in the markets, particularly in the Forex market.
explanation: The article suggests a relatively quiet day in European trading due to a sparse economic calendar, with only the French consumer confidence report due. However, the announcement by US President Trump that he intends to fire Fed governor Cook has sent the dollar lower, indicating increased market volatility. Although the dollar has clawed back some of its initial losses, the potential legal hurdles that need to be navigated before Governor Cook can be removed from her position are likely to cause further uncertainty in the markets. Additionally, the steepening of the US yield curve post-Jackson Hole is quietly making waves and is something to be watched in the weeks ahead. The European markets are expected to heat up on Friday with the release of inflation numbers. Overall, the events described in the article are likely to have a negative impact on the Forex and European markets.

title: France August consumer confidence 87 vs 89 expected
description:
• Prior 89; revised to 88

French household confidence dips further in August, falling to its lowest since October 2023. Unemployment expectations continue to stay elevated while the opinion on the standard of living also declined further. On the latter, the sub-index for the future standard of living declined another two points to -64 - its lowest since March 2023.

This article was written by Justin Low at investinglive.com.
markets: Consumer Confidence, Unemployment, Standard of Living
patterns: Similar to the dip in consumer confidence and standard of living in France during the 2008 financial crisis.
explanation: The French consumer confidence in August has dipped to 87, below the expected 89, marking a decrease from the prior 89, which was later revised to 88. This dip in consumer confidence is concerning as it has fallen to its lowest since October 2023. Additionally, the expectations of unemployment continue to stay high, which could potentially lead to a decrease in consumer spending and a slowdown in the French economy. The opinion on the standard of living has also declined further, with the sub-index for the future standard of living falling another two points to -64, its lowest since March 2023. This indicates a pessimistic outlook on the French economy, as a decrease in consumer confidence and standard of living often precedes an economic downturn. Therefore, this news is bearish for the French economy and markets related to consumer confidence, unemployment, and standard of living.

title: Billions wiped off value of French banks with Bayrou-led government on verge of collapse
description: French banking giants BNP Paribas and Societe Generale saw billions of euros wiped off their market value on Tuesday as the government of the eurozone’s number-two economy was set for collapse.
patterns: Similar to the 2008 financial crisis when instability in the government led to a significant decrease in the market value of banks.
explanation: The news indicates a significant negative sentiment towards the French banking sector, specifically BNP Paribas and Societe Generale, as a result of the potential collapse of the government led by Bayrou. This is a bearish signal for the banking sector and the Eurozone economy as a whole. Political instability often leads to economic uncertainty, which can negatively affect investor confidence. This can result in capital outflows from the banking sector and a decrease in the market value of banks. The situation is similar to the 2008 financial crisis, where government instability led to a significant decrease in the market value of banks. Given the size and importance of BNP Paribas and Societe Generale, this could have a wider impact on the European banking sector and the Eurozone economy.

title: Nasdaq Technical Analysis for Today with tradeCompass
description:
Nasdaq Futures Technical Analysis for Today with tradeCompass (August 26, 2025)

Current price (NQ): $23,437 (≈-0.25% vs. yesterday’s close) Recent context: All-time high on Aug 13 at $24,068.50, a 5-day pullback of -4.32% to $23,035 (near the $23k round number), a 2-day bounce to $23,650 (pivot), and now trading just beneath an important July pivot zone around $23,425–$23,450.

Summary for Nasdaq 100 Futures Traders Today

Decision Range: $23,445 – $23,480 (key cluster of levels) Bearish below: $23,463 (yesterday’s VAL single-price option) Bullish above: $23,513 (today’s POC) Primary bias: Bearish while price holds below the Decision Range

Sizing tip: If a 35-point band feels wide, trade the micro contract (MNQ). One MNQ “point” is 1/10th the dollar value of the E-mini, letting you express the same idea with tighter sizing.

Analysis of Nasdaq Futures Today: Market Context & Directional Bias

Price sits below the $23,445–$23,480 Decision Range, keeping the session tilted bearish unless buyers reclaim the band. For traders who prefer a single trigger, the bearish threshold is $23,463 (below yesterday’s Value Area Low), while bulls need to sustain above $23,513 (today’s Point of Control) to argue for upside continuation toward the upper pivots cited below.

Partial Profit Targets for Nasdaq Bears Today (once price is below our bearish threshold)

$23,417 — aligns with the 2nd lower VWAP deviation; frequent intraday magnet when momentum builds. $23,400 — round-number liquidity pocket where stops often cluster. $23,374 — nearby acceptance zone that can stall first legs.

Swing-extension waypoints for bears (if momentum persists): $23,312 — just above Aug 22 VAH; prior acceptance often retests. $23,276 — in line with Aug 24 VWAP; fair-value pullback idea. $23,226 — set above Aug 22 POC to capture reaction risk. $23,123 — above Aug 22 VAL; deeper test of that value area.

Stop logic for shorts: Your maximum protective stop should not sit beyond the top of the Decision Range ($23,482), because acceptance above that band weakens the short premise. Conservative traders may even key off a 15-min close above $23,513 (today’s POC) as full invalidation.

Partial Profit Targets for Nasdaq Bulls Today (once price sustains above our bullish threshold)

$23,531 — today’s VWAP; first fair-value magnet overhead. $23,543 — yesterday’s VAH; typical reaction level after reclaiming POC/VWAP. $23,575 — set just below Aug 20 VAH to front-run supply. $23,665 — just below Aug 12 VAL; higher-timeframe inflection. $23,695 — final swing target in this compass; beyond here awaits a new tradeCompass.

Stop logic for longs: A break back below $23,445 (bottom of the Decision Range) returns price to bearish territory—longs should not persist beneath the opposite bias.

How to Use This Compass

  • If price probes the Decision Range but fails to hold above it, shorts remain favored.

  • If price accepts above $23,513 (POC), the bull plan activates; use the targets listed and manage risk as below.

  • One trade per direction per tradeCompass. If you took the short plan and later got stopped at breakeven after partials, you do not re-short in this same compass. The same applies to the long plan.

Trade Management Essentials (read this!)

  • Take partials at logical magnets (VWAP, VAH/VAL, round numbers) to bank progress and lower stress.

  • After the second target is achieved, move your stop to entry—standard tradeCompass protocol.

  • Stops are tied to bias: never beyond the opposite side’s invalidation (e.g., above the Decision Range for shorts).

  • Confirmations are flexible: some wait for a 5–15 minute close through thresholds; others use order-flow cues. Choose what fits your playbook.

Quick Education: Why Partial Profits Matter (today’s lesson)

Markets often react at institutional price landmarks—VWAP, POC, VAH/VAL, and round-number liquidity pools. Scaling out at those junctions converts open risk into realized gain and gives you optionality for the runner. It’s not about perfection; it’s about systematically harvesting edges where big players transact.

tradeCompass is a decision-support framework. It does not tell you what to do; it maps the terrain so you can act with intent. Trade at your own risk. Futures are volatile, and losses can exceed deposits.

Stay updated & get ideas: Join our Telegram channel investingLive Stocks.

This article was written by Itai Levitan at investinglive.com.
patterns: The pattern observed here is similar to the market behavior in the second week of August when NASDAQ futures experienced a pullback after reaching an all-time high.
explanation: The article provides a detailed technical analysis of the NASDAQ futures for August 26, 2025. The current price of the NASDAQ futures is $23,437, down by 0.25% from the previous day's close. The NASDAQ futures have been experiencing a downward trend since reaching an all-time high on August 13 at $24,068.50. The bearish trend is likely to continue as the price is currently below the Decision Range of $23,445 – $23,480. The bearish threshold is $23,463, below yesterday’s Value Area Low (VAL), while the bullish threshold is $23,513, today’s Point of Control (POC). The primary bias remains bearish as long as the price remains below the Decision Range. The article also provides specific price targets for both bearish and bullish scenarios, along with strategies for managing trades in both scenarios.
